There’s a laugh bubbling up in my chest, and I let it escape, surprising myself. I set the condom down on top of the chaos, suddenly inspired. Maybe this is the universe’s way of nudging me, a silent dare to shake off my routine. So, I draft a message to my best friend: "Emergency adventure tonight?"—and snap a picture of the condom as proof that spontaneity is alive and well in the mess of adulthood. The reply comes back instantly: "Only if you wear your lucky socks." I grin, sweep the desk clean with one dramatic gesture, and start plotting. Tonight, the office supplies can fend for themselves.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

responses.text:
But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I learned this on a Tuesday, when the air was thick with the scent of rain and the city’s lights blurred behind my window. My friends called, inviting me to their rooftop gathering, promising laughter and music. I almost said yes, wanting to remember how it felt to let go. But the ache nudged me back, reminding me of the silence in the apartment and the echo of a voice that once told me jokes at midnight.

Instead, I sat by the window, watching droplets race each other down the glass, tracing paths that ended in puddles. I tried to chuckle at an old sitcom, but the sound came out brittle, like something broken. Yet, in that quiet, I noticed a neighbor’s dog chasing its tail in the courtyard, relentless and dizzy. For a moment, I smiled, small and real. Maybe, I thought, sadness is just a passing storm, and laughter returns like sunlight—soft at first, then bright enough to fill the room again.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I remember the first time I noticed this: sitting at the kitchen table, sunlight falling in pale stripes across my coffee cup, the world outside vibrating with the promise of spring. My sister sent me a joke—a silly meme about cats—but my lips barely twitched. The ache had settled into my bones, heavy and persistent.

Days passed like this: the world moved on, laughter echoing in the distance, just out of reach. I watched people on the street throw their heads back, carefree and joyful. I envied them, but I also knew that my sadness was something I had to carry, at least for now. One evening, as the sky blushed pink, I caught my reflection in the window, and for the first time, I smiled at myself—not because I was happy, but because I realized I was still here, still trying. And that, I thought, was a start.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

responses.text:
But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I learned this in the quiet hours after the world had gone to sleep, when the only sounds were the creaks of the old house and my own heartbeat. My mother used to say that laughter was medicine, but now, even the funniest memories seem muffled, like they’re wrapped in thick wool. 

Last night, I tried to watch my favorite comedy, hoping for relief. The screen glowed, the characters danced across it, but every joke bounced off the heavy shield I wore. The ache stayed, stubborn and unmoved. Still, I keep trying. I send silly texts to friends, force smiles at strangers, and hum cheerful tunes while making tea. Some days the effort feels pointless, but a single, unexpected chuckle breaks through, and I cling to it, hoping that tomorrow there will be more. Maybe one day laughter will come easier, and the ache won’t feel so heavy after all.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I noticed it most when I reunited with old friends at the familiar café, their voices rising and falling in waves of stories and jokes. I tried to join in, smiled at the right moments, but every laugh caught in my throat—like trying to sing through a mouthful of stones.

Afterward, I walked home alone along the riverbank, the city lights shimmering on the water. I remembered a time when laughter bubbled up easily, reckless and warm. Now, it seemed to come from far away, echoing in a place I couldn’t quite reach. Still, as I watched a stray cat chase its own tail under a streetlamp, I felt the corners of my mouth twitch. It wasn’t much, but it was something. Maybe, I thought, the ache doesn’t last forever. Maybe laughter will find its way back, one fragile smile at a time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh.

responses.text:
But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. It’s as if every joke is a stone skipping across a dark pond—ripples form, but never reach the other side. I carry that ache with me into the bustling market, where vendors shout and children weave between stalls. Their laughter floats on the air, light as silk scarves, but mine is lost somewhere behind my ribs. 

A woman selling oranges offers me a slice, her smile bright and effortless. I accept, hoping the citrus tang will shock my senses awake. For a moment, the flavor cuts through the gloom, sharp and alive. I almost laugh when the juice dribbles down my chin, but the ache returns before the sound escapes.

Still, I linger in the market, letting the noise and color press against my sadness. I think maybe if I stay long enough, the laughter will seep into my skin and root out the ache. Or maybe, I’ll just learn to carry both—the ache and the laughter—until they find a way to live together.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If she could unravel it.

responses.text: If she could unravel it. That was the thought echoing through Mira’s mind as she sat before the tangled heap of golden thread. The tapestry was old—older than her grandmother, older perhaps than memory itself. Each knot, each twist of the shimmering fiber, seemed to hide a secret. As her slender fingers worked gently, Mira imagined undoing not just the tangled threads, but the mysteries of her own past. Each loop that came free revealed a delicate pattern—a forgotten name here, a faded face there. The tapestry whispered stories as she worked late into the night. Her doubts and fears, too, seemed to loosen with each undoing. And as dawn crept through her window, Mira saw what she had uncovered: not just a tapestry restored, but a lineage reclaimed, threads of love and loss woven together, made whole again by the patience of her hands and the courage of her heart. If she could unravel it, she realized, she could begin anew.

If she could unravel it. That was all Lila could think as she stared at the knot of memories inside her mind. Each strand seemed to twist tighter when she tried to understand where things had gone wrong—her mother’s laughter turning to silence, the way the sunlit kitchen turned cold. If only she could find the beginning of the thread, pull gently, and watch the confusion fall away. She closed her eyes and imagined herself a weaver, patiently working through each tangled thought. Sometimes, she felt progress—a flash of clarity, a half-remembered smile. Other times, frustration threatened to overwhelm her. But she kept going, picking at the knots, refusing to give up. One morning, as dawn painted her room in gold, she felt the tangle loosen. In its place, she found not answers, but a gentle acceptance. Some knots, she realized, were meant to be carried, not undone. And with that, she let herself rest.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If she could unravel it.

responses.text: If she could unravel it. The thought pulsed through Amara's mind as she stared at the cryptic letter on her desk. The paper, yellowed with age, was covered in loops and swirls—an indecipherable code that her grandmother had left behind. Amara traced the lines with her finger, feeling each bump where the ink had bled. What secrets lay hidden in those curls? She spent nights cross-referencing symbols, searching old journals, even dreaming in spirals. One evening, a sudden insight struck her: the pattern of the markings matched the path of the river winding behind her childhood home. Heart pounding, Amara overlaid a map atop the letter. The code unlocked—a story of love, loss, and resilience written in the landscape itself. By unravelling the mystery, Amara not only uncovered her family’s forgotten history but also found the courage to write her own.

If she could unravel it. That simple hope was all that kept Petra returning to the attic each day. The old box of letters, bound with twine and dust, was a puzzle she couldn’t resist. Each envelope revealed fragments—a photograph torn at the edge, a ticket to a forgotten play, words that hinted at a secret never spoken. Petra’s curiosity grew with every page she read, piecing together the life of the ancestor she never met. The more she discovered, the more the lines between past and present blurred. In the shadows of the attic, time seemed to coil and unwind, and Petra wondered if she was unraveling the story or if it was unraveling her. When she finally reached the last letter, she realized that some mysteries weren’t meant to be solved completely. Instead, they became threads woven into her own story, binding her to those who came before.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If she could unravel it.

responses.text: If she could unravel it. The sky was knotted with storm clouds, thick and restless above the city lights, and Marian pressed her fingertips against the cool glass of her window, watching their slow, churning dance. She imagined the clouds as a skein of tangled yarn, threads of rain and thunder looped and twisted by unseen hands. If only she could reach up, pluck at the loose edges, and smooth the turmoil into calm, blue clarity. Perhaps then the city would breathe easier, and she, too, would find peace. Instead, Marian took her old violin and played a melody that mimicked the storm—first wild and chaotic, then gentle and soothing. Outside, the clouds shifted minutely, and a single star winked through. Maybe, she thought, unraveling the world’s knots wasn’t about force or understanding, but about meeting chaos with music, with hope, and finding the small, shining spaces in between.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: So how old are you?” Ben asks.

responses.text:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Lila hesitates, her fingers tracing the rim of her coffee cup. The café is nearly empty, sunlight slanting across their table, dust motes dancing lazily. “It’s complicated,” she says, voice barely above a whisper.

Ben laughs, thinking she’s joking. “Come on, it can’t be that bad. Twenty-eight? Thirty?”

She shakes her head, a wistful smile on her lips. “Try one hundred and thirty-two.”

Ben blinks, unsure if he’s heard her right. “Excuse me?”

She leans in, her eyes suddenly ancient and knowing. “I stopped counting birthdays after my hundredth. Time just… flows differently for me.”

He stares at her, searching for a hint of playfulness, a wink, anything to betray a joke. But Lila’s gaze is unwavering.

“Is this some kind of game?” he asks.

She shrugs. “You asked. I answered.”

Outside, a bell chimes as someone enters the café. For a moment, Ben wonders if he’s stepped into a storybook world—one where strangers could be centuries old, and secrets are waiting to be told over coffee.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Maya glances at him, then at the fading sunlight outside the window. The question lingers between them, heavier than it should be. She stirs her tea, as if the swirling leaves could offer up an answer.

“Old enough to know better,” she finally replies, her tone teasing but guarded.

Ben smiles, undeterred. “That’s not an answer.”

Maya looks away, her fingers tracing a scar on her wrist. “Sometimes, I feel ancient. Like I’ve lived a dozen lives. Other days, I feel like a child, stumbling through the dark.”

He leans forward, curiosity bright in his eyes. “What does that mean?”

She considers, then shrugs. “It means age is a trick of the mind. Some memories weigh more than years.”

Ben is silent, taking in the strange gravity of her words. Outside, the city hums; inside, Maya’s past stretches out, a shadow neither of them is quite ready to name.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: So how old are you?” Ben asks.

responses.text:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Jenna smiles, her eyes reflecting the flicker of candlelight between them. "Old enough to have stories, young enough to still believe in magic," she replies, her tone enigmatic.

Ben chuckles, swirling the wine in his glass. "That’s not a number."

She leans forward, lowering her voice. "Numbers miss the point. If I told you I was thirty, would you see me differently?"

He considers, surprised by the depth in her question. "Maybe. I guess we all try to fit people into boxes."

Jenna’s gaze holds his. "I’d rather you ask me about the time I chased a sunrise up a mountain, or the year I learned to forgive myself."

Ben finds himself wanting to know every story. "Tell me about the mountain."

She grins, the years in her eyes momentarily replaced by something wild and free. "It was the day I decided to stop waiting for life to happen."

Outside, the night deepens, but inside, the conversation unfurls with possibility, age forgotten in the glow of shared secrets.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Marcus fiddles with his watch, glancing at the train schedule flashing overhead. “Depends who’s asking,” he answers, half-smiling. “If you’re my landlord, I’m too old for late rent. If you’re my mom, I’m still her baby. If you’re you… I guess I’m twenty-four.”

Ben laughs, nudging Marcus with his shoulder. “You guess?”

Marcus shrugs. “Some days it feels like I’m eighty. Other days, like I just learned how to tie my shoes.”

The train thunders into the station, wind whipping their hair. Ben watches Marcus, noticing the tiredness beneath his grin. “Well, to me, you look exactly twenty-four.”

Marcus grins, boarding the train with Ben. “Good. Let’s go act like it, then.”

The doors slide closed, and as the city blurs past the window, Marcus feels, for a moment, exactly the right age: somewhere between yesterday’s worries and tomorrow’s hopes.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: So how old are you?” Ben asks.

responses.text:
"So how old are you?" Ben asks.

The question hangs in the air between the two of them, echoing louder than the hum of the laundromat's dryers. The stranger, clad in a patched army jacket and mismatched socks, considers his reflection in the window before answering.

"I’m as old as the stories I carry," he says finally, stuffing another faded shirt into the machine. "Some days, I’m the ten-year-old who caught frogs by the creek. Other days, I’m the forty-year-old who watched the world unravel from a hospital bed. But right now," he glances at Ben, a crooked smile on his lips, "I’m just old enough to know that every answer is a beginning."

Ben folds a towel, suddenly aware of the many lives each person might live in a single lifetime. The dryers beep and spin, cycling jeans and memories alike. He thinks about the question again, and wonders if maybe, in the end, it’s not about the number at all, but the stories you’re willing to tell.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:
He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The summer sun glinted off the faded blue fabric as he approached, careful not to jostle the contents. He could feel the uneven lumps inside—some heavy, some soft. As he reached his mother, she took the bag from him and set it down gently on the picnic blanket.  

"Thank you, Jamie," she said, her eyes searching his face for traces of the excitement she remembered from her own childhood.

He watched as she opened the bag, revealing a collection of polished river stones, bits of colored glass, and a single, perfectly round apple. The treasures from their morning walk, small but significant. His mother smiled, pulling out the apple and slicing it for them to share. 

"It's the little things," she whispered. Jamie grinned, feeling the warmth of the sun and the quiet magic of the moment.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The market was busy, the air thick with the scent of spices and fresh bread, but he felt a surge of pride as he navigated back to her side. She pulled him close, inspecting the bag’s contents—a bundle of fresh herbs, a wedge of cheese, and the shiny red apple she always bought for him.

“Good work, Sami,” she whispered, slipping the apple into his hand. He grinned, biting into it as they continued through the market. Each step was a lesson: when to barter, how to pick ripe produce, how to blend in and yet stand out. By the time they left, arms full and hearts light, Sami knew he’d remember this day—not just for the taste of the apple, but for the way his mother squeezed his hand, proud and trusting.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:
He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The old barn was dim, dust motes swirling in the sunlight that slipped through the cracks. He stepped carefully, the bag swinging gently by his side as he made his way back. His mother waited near the workbench, her eyes soft but tired.

She took the bag from him and reached inside, pulling out the bundle of seeds they’d saved last season. "We’ll plant these together," she said, her voice hopeful. He watched as she set the seeds in neat piles, her hands steady despite everything. The barn felt warmer, safer, as they prepared for spring.

They worked side by side, digging small holes and placing the seeds, talking about what might grow. Outside, the frost still clung to the grass, but inside, the promise of new life was enough. As dusk fell, he looked over at his mother and smiled, the cloth bag empty now but his heart full.

He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. He could tell by the way her eyes softened, her usual sternness relaxing as she beckoned him over.

"Come here, Daniel. Let me see," she said. He shuffled forward, the bag clutched close. She opened it, her hands deft and practiced, and drew out the small wooden box hidden inside. Daniel watched, heart pounding, as she opened the lid to reveal a handful of coins and a faded photograph.

She smiled—a rare, gentle thing. "This was your grandfather’s. He would have wanted you to have it now."

Daniel’s fingers trembled as he accepted the box. In that moment, the weight of family history settled on his shoulders, but it felt like a gift rather than a burden. He looked up, meeting his mother’s gaze, and understood that he had taken his first step into a world much bigger than himself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one.

responses.text:
He emerged with the cloth bag, holding it aloft until his mother nodded to indicate he had gotten the right one. The air in the workshop was thick with the scent of varnish and old wood, motes of dust dancing in the golden afternoon light. He approached her, feeling the anticipation build in his chest. She set aside her carving tools and gently untied the bag’s drawstring, revealing a collection of tiny clockwork gears and a faded brass key. With a knowing smile, she handed him the smallest gear and nodded toward the half-finished automaton on the table. 

"It’s time you try," she said. 

His hands trembled, but excitement overrode his nerves. With careful concentration, he fitted the gear into the heart of the mechanical bird. As he turned the brass key, the automaton whirred to life, its wings fluttering. For a moment, mother and son watched it soar in a circle, a testament to patience, trust, and the magic of small beginnings.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips.

responses.text:
But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The ragtime tune stutters, catching on a scratch that wasn’t there before. Mrs. Baker freezes, one hand on the ornate brass handle. The silence pulses, heavy and expectant, as the air seems to thicken. The skipping repeats—a hollow, popping echo—until the record finally halts with a low, mournful whine.

She glances over her shoulder, heart pounding. The parlor is empty, but somehow she feels watched. She tries to laugh off the tension, but as she turns back, a faint whisper seeps from behind the armoire doors, so soft it might be in her own head.

Her fingers tremble as she pulls the doors open. Inside, instead of the usual stack of linens, she finds a single, yellowed letter addressed to her maiden name. The ink is faded, but she recognizes the handwriting instantly—her father’s, gone these twenty years. As thunder rolls outside, Mrs. Baker realizes the record has begun to play again, but this time, the voice singing is unmistakably her father’s.

But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The scratchy jazz melody wobbles, and then the room is filled with silence. Mrs. Baker’s hand hovers in the air, uncertain. For a moment, she wonders if she imagined it, but then a single note warbles out from the gramophone, lower and slower than before.

She glances back at the old machine, frowning. It’s been acting strangely all week, ever since the storm knocked out the power and she’d lit candles to keep the darkness at bay. Another skip, and the tune resumes, this time backwards, a haunting reversal of the melody she knows so well.

A chill creeps up her spine. She turns back to the armoire, but now something seems different about it. The wood grain swirls in odd patterns, almost as if moving. Gathering her courage, Mrs. Baker finally pulls the doors open, only to find not her winter coats, but a spiral staircase leading down into blue-lit shadows she’s never seen before.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips.

responses.text:
But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The lilting waltz grates, then halts, and the needle scrapes in a jarring loop. Mrs. Baker’s breath catches—she’s always been superstitious about interruptions. She steps away from the armoire, her gaze fixed on the spinning vinyl, which now spins faster than it should. 

The room, heavy with lavender and dust, seems to lean in. She crosses to the record player, intent on lifting the needle, but it lowers itself—slowly, deliberately—onto a new track. This song she does not recognize: a low, scratchy lullaby, sung in a voice that sounds eerily like her grandmother’s. 

Hands trembling, Mrs. Baker turns back to the armoire. The doors, once tightly shut, now stand slightly ajar. Inside, the folds of an old wedding dress flutter as though stirred by a breeze. A lavender sachet tumbles to the floor, and for the first time in decades, Mrs. Baker hears her grandmother’s voice clearly: “Come closer, child.”

But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The gentle hum of Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata falters, then picks up at a dissonant, frantic tempo. Mrs. Baker withdraws her hand, startled by the abrupt change. 

She turns, expecting to see her grandson fiddling with the record player again, but the room is empty save for her own shadow. The music distorts, echoing oddly off the high ceilings. The armoire rattles, as though something inside is knocking to get out. Mrs. Baker’s heart pounds; she’s sure she locked it tight just this morning.

The record player groans, the melody twisting into unfamiliar minor chords. Mrs. Baker hesitates. She takes a deep breath, squares her shoulders, and opens the armoire doors. Inside, she finds not the usual neatly folded linens, but an old phonograph horn and a single, black feather. From somewhere deep within the armoire, a soft, unearthly melody begins to play, beckoning her forward.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips.

responses.text:
But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. The haunting melody dissolves into static, and then, quite impossibly, a voice crackles through the speakers: "Don’t open it. Not yet." Mrs. Baker’s fingers freeze on the ornate handles. She scans the empty room, heart racing, but the voice is unmistakably her own—though distant and warped by time. 

Confused, she takes a shaky step back. The air thickens, shimmering with a strange heat. The armoire’s carved roses seem to pulse, and for an instant, the whole room flickers as if caught in a lightning storm. Mrs. Baker’s mind reels with memories she can’t quite place: a childhood game, a hidden key, her mother’s urgent whispers. 

The record resumes, but now the music is reversed, each note unraveling the past. Mrs. Baker realizes, with a shiver, that the armoire is more than a cupboard. It’s a door—one she’s opened before, in dreams she was meant to forget. And this time, whatever’s behind it is waiting for her to remember.

Its silver surface was dented and tarnished, but as she wound the key, a gentle melody filled the room, echoing off the rafters. For a moment, they sat together, memories of family and laughter hanging between them, the attic transformed into a place of magic. Carefully, she opened the bag, revealing a bundle of seeds wrapped in crinkled parchment. “These are special,” she whispered. “Your grandfather grew them in his garden before the war.” His eyes widened as he peered inside—tiny seeds, but full of promise. That evening, they planted them together behind their small house, hands muddy and hearts hopeful. As dusk settled, he glanced at his mother, who looked out at the freshly turned earth with pride. He didn’t know what would grow, but he understood that hope, like seeds, needed only a little care to flourish.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. I can’t tell if she’s angry, amused, or just tired. The hallways of the museum echo with our footsteps, and I slow down, hoping she’ll say something. She doesn’t. Instead, she stops at the massive oak doors leading to the west wing and waits. I hesitate at her side, searching her face for a hint. Nothing. 

“Should we?” I ask, nodding at the doors. She shrugs and pushes them open. The gallery is empty except for a single painting on the far wall: a storm-tossed sea under a bruised sky. Michaela steps closer, her expression finally softening. “You said you wanted to see something real,” she says quietly. “Here it is.”

I want to ask what she means, but something in the way she stands—shoulders tensed, fists unclenched—makes me stay quiet. We stand together in the silence, letting the painting’s wild energy wash over us. For the first time since we arrived, I feel like we’re seeing the same thing.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The gravel crunches beneath our feet as we walk deeper into the garden, the night air heavy with the scent of jasmine. I try to read her silence, but it’s as impenetrable as the shadows gathering under the old oak trees. I want to ask why she insisted we come here, but her pace quickens, urging me on.

We reach the farthest bench, hidden from the house’s glow. Michaela sits and gestures for me to join her. I hesitate, then comply, feeling the damp chill of the stone through my jeans. She finally speaks, her voice low. “Do you remember the promise we made here?”

I nod, heart pounding. How could I forget? The memory is stitched into the fabric of this place. She turns to me, her eyes shining in the moonlight, and the unreadable look melts away, replaced by something raw and familiar. “It’s time to keep it,” she whispers, and in that moment, the garden feels like the edge of the world—fragile, expectant, waiting for us to decide.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. We step through the rusted gate, its hinges groaning in protest. The path ahead is choked with weeds, and the air hums with the promise of rain. I glance back at her, hoping for some sign—approval, reassurance, anything—but her face is a mask. We move forward in silence, boots sinking into the soft earth, until the path opens onto the old greenhouse.

Its glass panes are cracked, ivy crawling like veins across the frame. Michaela pauses, finally breaking her silence. "Do you really think it's still here?" she asks, voice barely above a whisper.

I nod, swallowing my nerves. "If anything survived, it'll be in there."

She exhales, uncertain, then pushes the door. The scent of damp earth and forgotten things floods out. Together, we step inside, searching for what we lost—unsure if we want to find it, or only to say we tried.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The corridor narrows, plaster peeling from the walls like old scars. I can sense her behind me, silent but present, her footsteps syncing with my own. At the end of the hall, a door waits—faded blue, handle tarnished with age.

I pause, pressing my palm against the wood. "Are you sure?" I ask, but Michaela doesn’t answer. Instead, she steps past me, her fingers brushing mine, and turns the handle. The door creaks open, revealing a room thick with dust and memory.

We enter together. Sunlight filters through broken blinds, illuminating boxes stacked against the walls. Michaela moves to one, kneels, and lifts the lid. Inside, photographs spill out—faces half-remembered, moments frozen in time. She looks up at me at last, her expression finally softening. "Let’s see what we missed," she says, and for the first time all day, I feel hope.

Michaela smiles—a real, crooked smile this time—and in the hush of the attic, I realize we’re not just searching for answers. We’re rewriting the story ourselves.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it.

responses.text:
I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it. The number on my online banking app shimmered like a mirage: $10,000,000.00. My hands shook as I refreshed the screen, convinced it was a glitch or a practical joke. But every time, the same unfathomable sum stared back at me. I retraced my steps, thinking back to the raffle ticket I’d bought last week at the grocery store. Could it be? I dug through my jacket pockets, heart pounding, until I found the crumpled ticket. The winning numbers matched. I’d won the jackpot.

But jubilation was quickly replaced by anxiety. Who else knew? Would everyone treat me differently now? And what would I do with so much money? I paced the room, phone in hand, resisting the urge to call everyone I knew. My cat, oblivious to my windfall, pawed at my shoelace. I scooped her up. “Don’t worry,” I whispered. “I’ll buy you all the tuna you want.”

Still, I kept counting the zeros, afraid they’d vanish if I looked away. Outside, the world went on as usual, but inside, everything had changed.

I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it. The old ledger, brittle and yellowed at the edges, was a relic from my grandfather’s days running the general store. I always assumed the family stories about hidden fortunes were just that—stories. But here, in black ink, was an entry with a number so large it made my head spin. Ten million dollars, listed as an outstanding deposit from some mysterious source.

My mind raced with possibilities. Had my grandfather laundered money for bootleggers during prohibition? Was there a secret inheritance I was never told about? The numbers didn’t lie, but the story behind them was buried in the past. I turned the page, searching for clues, and found a faded note: “Trust the safe.”

In the cellar, behind a row of dusty preserves, I found the old safe I’d always dismissed as empty. My hands trembled as I spun the combination, just as my grandfather had taught me as a child. When the door creaked open, I gasped. Inside wasn’t cash, but a stack of letters and a single golden coin. The real treasure, it seemed, was a secret waiting to be discovered.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it.

responses.text:
I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it. The printout from the observatory’s computer glowed softly under the red desk lamp. My research grant had been modest, the hours long, and the hope for a breakthrough faint. But the data was undeniable—a signal, stronger than background noise, coming from a distant star system. Not just a blip, but a pattern, encoded with mathematical precision. The energy levels were off the charts, orders of magnitude higher than anything we’d ever recorded. I blinked, then called in Dr. Morales from the next lab. Together, we ran the calculations again. The zeros lined up, each one a testament to the possibility that we weren’t alone. 

Excitement warred with disbelief as we debated what to do next. Should we alert the international team? Was it a fluke, or a message? I stared at the zeros, feeling the weight of discovery settle on my shoulders. Whatever happened next, tonight I knew the universe had just gotten a little bigger—and so had my place in it.

I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it. My inbox, usually a wasteland of spam and unanswered newsletters, now contained an email with the subject: "Congratulations, You Have Been Selected!" I almost deleted it, but curiosity—or maybe just boredom—got the better of me. The email claimed I’d won a grant worth one million dollars. At first, I laughed. Then I reread the message, noticing the sender was an official university address. The attachment looked legitimate, and the instructions were clear. 

I checked the university website, found my name listed among the recipients, and finally let myself believe it. The zeros were real. With this money, I could finally take my research to the next level, hire assistants, and travel to international conferences. My skepticism faded into exhilaration as I began to draft my acceptance letter, realizing this windfall could change the course of my entire career. Still, every few minutes, I returned to the email—just to count the zeros one more time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it.

responses.text: I had to count the zeros several times before I could believe it. There, on the dusty chalkboard in my grandfather’s attic, was an equation that had eluded mathematicians for decades. I thought it was some childish scribble, a remnant of his days teaching at the old university, but as I followed the symbols and the endless string of zeros, it dawned on me: this was a solution, elegant and unassuming, to the famed Goldstein Conundrum. My breath caught. If this proof held, it would rewrite textbooks, alter careers, and maybe even topple a few egos in the math world. I snapped photos, hands shaking, and emailed them to my old professor. Minutes later, my phone buzzed with a call. “Where did you find this?” he demanded, voice trembling. I glanced up at the sunlight pooling on the old floorboards and smiled. Sometimes, the greatest discoveries are hidden in the most ordinary places, waiting for someone to count the zeros and see the truth.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.’ The words echoed through the empty hall, bouncing from stone to stone, each syllable a reminder of the silence that now filled the world. Wulf’s hands, streaked with soot and dried blood, trembled as he gripped the hilt of his sword. The fires had died down hours ago, leaving only the smoldering remains of what was once a bustling town.

He walked, boots crunching through ash, past the remnants of his friends and foes alike. The wind carried the scent of loss, sharp and bitter. At the city’s edge, he paused. The sun was rising, weak and pale, as if mourning too. Wulf fell to his knees, the weight of survival crushing him. He had not asked to be spared, nor did he know why he was. ‘I will remember them,’ he whispered into the empty dawn. His voice was small, but it was a promise. In the quiet aftermath, Wulf stood, the only living testament to what had been. He started forward, carrying their memory into whatever future remained.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The old woman’s voice was little more than a whisper, thin as the morning mist curling around the ruins.

He stared across the field, where the sun glinted off twisted metal and broken banners. The battle had ended, but the cost was written everywhere: in the silence, in the air heavy with smoke, and in the emptiness where laughter and song once lived.

Wulf wrapped his cloak around his shoulders, feeling suddenly smaller. ‘What am I supposed to do now?’

She looked at him with tired eyes. ‘Survive. Remember. Begin again.’

He nodded, but the words tasted foreign. The world felt too large, too strange without the others. He took a step forward, boots crunching on scorched earth. Each footfall was a promise—not just to live, but to carry something of them with him. He would plant their stories like seeds in the blackened ground, hoping one day they would bloom again, bright and resilient, just as they had been.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words fell between them like stones, heavy and inevitable. Wulf stared at the charred earth, remembering laughter, the clang of swords, plans whispered late into the night. All gone now, swept away by flame and fury. He tried to recall the moment it had turned—the sky splitting with thunder, friends vanishing in a blink. Why him? Why not any of the others who were braver, kinder, wiser?

‘What am I supposed to do with this?’ he asked, his voice cracking.

The elder shrugged, eyes distant. ‘Live as witness. Let the world know they were here.’

Wulf pressed his palm to the ground, feeling the warmth fading beneath his fingers. He closed his eyes, breathing in the silence, and promised he would not let memory die. Rising, he took his first step toward the horizon, the weight of the lost pressing him forward, the only one left to tell their story.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

He stood on the edge of the ravaged village, smoke rising in lazy spirals from what was left of the homes. The silence was deafening, broken only by the distant caw of a crow. Wulf’s heart pounded, guilt and relief tangled in his chest. He remembered the chaos, the shouts, the fire. He remembered someone pulling him from the wreckage, but not who. Now, there was no one left to ask.

He wandered through the ashes, calling names, hoping for an answer. None came. With each step, he felt the enormity of survival settle on his shoulders. He was alive, but at what cost? He knelt before the well in the center of the square, whispering a promise to remember every face, every story. Then he rose, determined to carry their memory forward, even if he was the only one left to do so.

‘It appears so.’

A cold wind swept across the silent harbor, rattling the bones of broken ships. Wulf stared at the horizon, where the sun bled orange into the restless sea. He listened, hoping for another voice, a footstep, anything—but the world had fallen eerily still. The gulls no longer circled, and the air tasted of salt and endings.

He moved slowly among the wreckage, clutching the compass he had found in the captain’s cabin. Its needle spun wildly, as if lost without the others. Wulf remembered laughter on the decks, songs echoing in the night, the steady rhythm of oars. Now, only memory kept him company.

But as he traced the shoreline, he noticed something strange: a single, delicate flower blooming between shattered planks. Wulf knelt, awe prickling his skin. Life, persistent and defiant. He smiled for the first time, understanding. If he was the only one left, he would not mourn forever. Instead, he would plant seeds in the ashes, hoping one day someone would find them and know that he—and they—had lived.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils.

responses.text:
I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. The cluttered drawer in the teacher’s lounge has always been a mystery, but this was the last thing I expected to find. I turn it over in my hand, half-expecting it to be a joke left by one of the students trying to fluster us. But the expiration date is years away, and my cheeks flush with embarrassment. I look around, but the lounge is empty, save for the faint hum of the vending machine.

As I consider tossing it in the trash, a memory surfaces—last week, during the school’s awkward “health education” assembly, Mr. Turner had been looking for a demonstration model. He must have left it here in a hurry, probably too flustered to notice the chaos inside the drawer. Smiling to myself, I slip it into an envelope and leave it in his mailbox with a note: “Found your missing prop. Ready for round two?”

That afternoon, Mr. Turner’s bewildered laughter echoes down the hall, and for the first time in weeks, the teachers share a moment of levity.

Thanks for being part of his community! The message flashed on Mia’s phone as she stepped into the crowded auditorium. She found a seat in the back row and listened as the mayor spoke about the upcoming harvest festival. Afterward, a woman approached her with a warm smile. “I’m Karen, and I run the community garden. We could use a hand. Interested?”

Mia hesitated, then nodded. “I’d love to help.”

The next morning, she arrived at the garden, rolling up her sleeves alongside strangers who quickly became friends. Each weed she pulled, every seed she planted, seemed to root her deeper into the fabric of Willowbrook. By the festival, Mia wasn’t just another face in the crowd—she was part of the heart of the community, grateful for the invitation that started it all.

Thanks for being part of his community! The words echoed in Lila’s mind as she closed her laptop. She’d joined the online forum on a whim, searching for a sense of belonging after moving to a new city. But she hadn’t expected the warmth that greeted her—strangers offering advice, laughter, and even late-night movie marathons over video chat.

One evening, Lila noticed a post from Sam, the group’s founder. He needed volunteers for a local park cleanup. Nervous but eager, Lila signed up. The next Saturday, she found herself pulling weeds and laughing with Sam and the others. By the end of the day, her hands were dirty but her heart was full.

When Sam handed out thank-you notes, Lila realized she’d finally found her place. It wasn’t just about cleaning a park; it was about building something together. From that day on, Lila knew she was truly part of his community—and that made all the difference.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked, her voice barely rising above the hiss of the rain on the tin roof.

Mara paused at the window, watching the silhouette move in the lamplight across the road. “Not ships. Something else. He’s been collecting scraps—wood, metal, bits of wire. I saw him with an old radio last night.”

Alie pressed her face to the glass, squinting through the streaks. The figure bent over a workbench, intent and alone. “He never talks to anyone anymore.”

Mara shrugged. “Some people like to keep their secrets.”

A crack of thunder rattled the panes. Alie flinched. When she looked again, the lamp had gone out. The workshop was dark.

Later, when the storm passed, Alie slipped across the street and peered through the cracks in the wall. Inside, the man hunched over a strange contraption—a metal bird, wings spread, wires trailing like feathers.

She gasped. He looked up, eyes sharp in the gloom. “Curiosity is dangerous,” he said softly, “but sometimes, it’s the only thing that flies.”

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked, peering through the workshop window as the evening sun streaked the dust with gold.

Her brother, Finn, nodded. "I think so. He’s been in there every night since the harvest."

Alie pressed her forehead to the glass. The old man—their neighbor, Mr. Carrow—was hunched over a worktable. But the shapes he crafted didn’t look like ships at all. They were strange, with wings and wheels and propellers made from scraps.

"That’s not a ship," Alie whispered. "It’s something else."

Finn shrugged. "Maybe he wants to sail the sky."

They watched as Mr. Carrow attached a delicate wing to a frame. Then, with trembling hands, he wound a rubber band and released it. The contraption fluttered and soared across the room, landing softly on a pile of blueprints.

Alie smiled, her imagination catching fire. "Maybe, one day, we’ll build sky-ships, too."

Finn grinned. "Let’s ask him tomorrow. Maybe he’ll teach us how to fly."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked, her breath fogging the cold windowpane. In the dim light of the barn, she watched her grandfather stoop over his workbench, hands moving with practiced precision.

Uncle Joss nodded, a smile tugging at his lips. "Not ships, this time. Something new."

Alie pressed closer, her curiosity piqued. "What is it, then?"

"You’ll see," Joss replied, glancing toward the barn. "He says it’s for you."

The next morning, Alie hurried outside, boots squelching in the dew-soaked grass. Inside the barn, her grandfather unveiled a curious object—a boat with wings, patched together with sails and gears.

"It’s a dream-catcher," he explained, eyes twinkling. "For the journeys you haven’t dreamed yet."

Alie reached out, tracing the smooth curve of the hull. She imagined herself sailing above the clouds, stars within reach. The world outside seemed suddenly bigger, full of possibility. She grinned up at her grandfather. "Will you teach me to fly it?"

He nodded. "Of course. Every explorer needs a guide."

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked, craning her neck to see over the garden wall.

Her sister, Nora, shook her head. "I don’t think so. He’s always out there with the blueprints, but they look strange—long, thin, more like birds than boats."

Alie frowned, watching the old man in his yard. He hammered, bent, and shaped metal in ways she’d never seen before. "Maybe they’re flying ships."

Nora laughed. "Flying ships? You’ve been reading too many stories."

But Alie wasn’t so sure. That evening, under the cover of dusk, she crept closer. The contraption stood tall—wings like a dragonfly, a tail that flickered in the breeze.

As the stars blinked awake, the old man glanced up and winked. "Come back tomorrow, little one," he called. "Maybe I’ll show you how to set sail among the clouds."

Alie grinned, heart thumping. Perhaps some stories were true after all.

That night, unable to sleep, Alie crept outside. The shed door was ajar, spilling golden light and the scent of sawdust. Inside, her father and brother were piecing together a strange contraption—part boat, part kite, painted in colors from old birthday cards and faded photographs.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, 'Was I really the only one who lived?'

'It appears so.'

The words echoed through the charred remains of the citadel, mingling with the smoke that still rose from the broken stones. Wulf knelt beside a blackened spear, gripping the shaft as if it might anchor him to this reality. He tried to remember the faces of his companions—Orin’s laughter, Myra’s quick wit, even old Captain Joss’s gruff rebukes. But their images faded like ghosts in the haze.

He looked up at the figure who had answered him. Cloaked and shadowed, they stood apart, face unreadable. Wulf’s throat tightened. 'Why me?' he whispered.

The figure hesitated, then said, 'Sometimes fate chooses its survivors for reasons beyond our knowing.'

A hush settled. Somewhere beyond the ruins, a bird began to sing—a fragile, hopeful sound amid devastation. Wulf drew a trembling breath. He struggled to his feet, the spear supporting his weight. Whatever the reasons, he was alive. And now, as the only witness, it was his burden to remember, to rebuild, and perhaps, in time, to forgive.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’ The words hung between them, heavy as the smoke curling over the ruins. Wulf looked down at his hands, at the dirt beneath his nails, the blood turning brown on his skin. He remembered the screams, the fire, the way the world had turned upside down in a matter of minutes.

‘Why me?’ he asked, but the old woman beside him simply shook her head. ‘Survival is not a reward, Wulf. It is a question.’

He closed his eyes, listening to the distant crackle of dying flames. His memories blurred—the faces of friends, the laughter around the evening fire, the oath they’d all sworn. Gone, all of them. He was left with ashes and silence.

The old woman placed a hand on his shoulder. ‘You will carry their stories. That is how they live on.’

Wulf nodded, not trusting his voice. The path ahead was uncertain, but with each step, he would honor the fallen. That was the promise he made as the sun rose over the shattered land.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The cave was silent except for the distant drip of water. Wulf’s words seemed to linger in the damp air, unanswered by the shadows. He glanced at Mara, her face pale in the gloom, her eyes unreadable.

‘But I was at the edge,’ he said softly. ‘I ran. I didn’t even look back.’

Mara shifted, pulling her cloak tighter. ‘Sometimes, surviving is the hardest part. The others… they made their choices. You made yours.’

Wulf’s fingers trembled. The memory of fire, the rush of feet, the chaos as the world above collapsed—it pressed in on him, heavy and cold. ‘What do I do now?’

Mara looked at him, her gaze steady. ‘You live. That’s all any of us can do. And you remember.’

He closed his eyes, feeling the weight of solitude settle. The world was changed, but he was still here. For now, that would have to be enough.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The dawn’s pale light crept across the ruined field, glinting off shattered armor and twisted banners. Wulf staggered forward, numb, the echo of battle still ringing in his ears. The old healer, bent and gray, watched him quietly.

‘You should not have survived,’ she said, voice soft. ‘Yet here you stand.’

Wulf wanted to protest, to demand explanation, but his words came out as a whisper. ‘What am I supposed to do now?’

‘You honor them,’ the healer replied. ‘With every step you take. You carry their memory, their hopes.’

A crow hopped onto a broken helm, cawing into the silence. Wulf sank to his knees. He pressed his palm to the earth, feeling the cold seep in. He was alone, but not abandoned—he bore the weight of stories yet untold, and a future only he could shape.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The answer was delivered by the wind, sighing through the splintered ribs of the shipwreck. Salt crusted Wulf’s hair and stung his eyes, but he squinted into the gray dawn, searching for another soul—any sign of movement among the broken timbers and tangled nets.

He stumbled forward, boots crunching over washed-up memories: a child’s wooden toy, a tattered scarf, a single, muddy boot. He knelt beside the boot, gripping it with trembling fingers. The sea had taken them all—his friends, his kin—leaving him alone with the shrieking gulls.

‘What am I supposed to do now?’ he whispered.

The wind offered no advice, only a bitter, briny laugh. But as he rose, a flash of silver caught his eye. A tiny fish, alive in a puddle, gasped at the sky. Wulf scooped it up, cradling it gently. He carried it to the edge of the surf and let it slip away. 

‘If the sea gives me one more chance,’ Wulf said, ‘I’ll find a way to honor them.’

The morning sun broke through, and Wulf began to walk, following the coastline into the unknown.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’ ‘It appears so.

responses.text:
Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

The words echoed in the dim chamber as Wulf’s eyes adjusted to the soft, flickering light. He shivered, memories of the storm still pulsing behind his eyes—the crash, the surge of water, the desperate grasp for air. Now, all that remained was silence, broken only by the distant drip of water and the steady breathing of the stranger who had answered him.

Wulf looked down at his hands. Scratched, shaking, but alive. He tried to remember each face from the ship: old Bryn with her laugh, the twins who sang as they worked, even the captain whose commands still rang in his ears. Gone. All gone.

The stranger stepped closer, revealing a face lined with both sorrow and resolve. ‘You’ll need your strength. There’s a long journey ahead, and little comfort to be found in memories.’

Wulf straightened his back, swallowing the ache in his chest. He nodded, feeling the weight of survival settle over him like a cloak. The world had changed, but Wulf remained. For now, that would have to be enough.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

Wulf stared at the smoldering wreckage below, the acrid scent of burnt wood and metal stinging his nose. It was difficult to believe: the thunderous storm, the frantic shouts, the desperate fight to stay above water—all seemed distant now, as if they belonged to someone else. His hands trembled as he clutched the blanket wrapped around his shoulders.

‘How did I survive?’ he whispered. The figure beside him—a woman with a face weathered by hardship—shook her head.

‘Sometimes, the sea chooses who will walk away.’

He forced himself to look again at the twisted shapes, the remnants of his world scattered across the shore. There was no sign of the others. Only seagulls circled above, crying out in the gray morning light.

‘What do I do now?’

The woman gazed at him with quiet sympathy. ‘You live. You remember. And you find a way to begin again.’

Wulf closed his eyes, letting the wind wash over him, and for the first time since the storm, allowed himself to hope.

‘It appears so.’

The words hung in the chill morning air like mist. Wulf’s boots crunched on the frostbitten grass as he surveyed the remnants of the camp. The fires had burned low, leaving only scorched earth and the memory of laughter. He knelt, fingers sifting through cold ashes, searching for something—anything—to prove the world he knew hadn’t vanished.

The figure beside him, cloaked in gray, placed a gentle hand on his shoulder. ‘You were found by the river. The rest… we found no one else.’

Wulf swallowed, throat thick. ‘Why me? Why not—’

The figure shook their head. ‘Fate is never so simple. Come. There’s shelter beyond the ridge. Others will want to know your story.’

With leaden steps, Wulf rose, casting one last glance at the ruins. He carried the weight of all those lost, and with it, the fragile hope that perhaps survival meant more than just being alive.

Wulf said, ‘Was I really the only one who lived?’

‘It appears so.’

A silence followed, heavy as the dawn fog curling between the splintered trees. Wulf pressed his palms against the damp moss, feeling the pulse of the earth beneath, as if searching for other heartbeats. Broken banners and shattered shields littered the ground around him; only the crows bore witness to what had occurred.

He could not remember how he had survived when so many others had not. The stranger who stood over him, face hidden beneath a hood, offered neither comfort nor explanation. Instead, they extended a hand, gloved and steady.

‘What now?’ Wulf asked, voice barely above a whisper.

‘Now you decide what to do with the life you have been given, and the stories you carry.’

Wulf hesitated, then took the hand. The first step away from the battlefield was the hardest, but he took it, uncertain but alive.

‘It appears so.’

The world had collapsed into a hush, broken only by the distant crackle of fire in the ruins below. Wulf stood atop the hill, his silhouette framed by the bruised sky, and tried to remember his own name—how strange it sounded now, echoing in a place emptied of all others. He turned to the old woman who had answered him, her face creased like the maps he once pored over in happier days.

‘Something must be left,’ he murmured, searching the valley for movement, for hope. The woman shook her head slowly, her eyes reflecting both sorrow and a quiet understanding. ‘Sometimes, survival is not a gift, but a question. What will you do with it?’

A wind stirred, scattering ash and memory. Wulf’s heart hammered. He took a step forward, uncertain, but resolved. If he was the only one left, then he would become the memory-bearer, the story-keeper. Even among ghosts, he would not let them be forgotten.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. She pressed her forehead to the cold glass, peering across the bay where the hulls of half-built vessels rose like skeletons against the bruise-colored sky.

Her father watched her from his seat by the stove. “Aye,” he replied, voice rough from years at sea. “Everyone’s building something these days. Even your brother.”

Alie’s heart thudded. She remembered the summer when she and her brother had floated toy boats in the creek, pretending to command armadas. Now he spent long days in the shipyard, hammering and sawing beside men twice his age.

“But why?” she asked quietly.

Her father’s eyes drifted to the window. “Because storms are coming. Not just of wind and rain.”

Alie pressed her hand to the glass, as if she could reach him across the bay. She wondered what kind of ship her brother was building, and where it might carry him when the storms finally broke.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked. Her mother paused, the knitting needles in her lap clattering softly. Outside, the old harbor gleamed under the morning sun, dotted with the silhouettes of half-finished vessels and the distant figures of men at work.

"He is," her mother said, voice tinged with both pride and worry. "Like his father, and his father before him."

Alie bit her lip, remembering the way her brother had talked about the sea—how it called to him. But she had also seen the longing in his eyes for something more than wood and water. "Do you think he'll stay?"

Her mother sighed, setting aside her yarn. "The sea takes what it wants, Alie. Ships are only the beginning."

Alie stared out at the bustling docks, feeling a strange mix of hope and dread. Maybe her brother was building more than ships; maybe he was building a way to leave, or a way to come home again. She pressed her hand to the window, wishing she could know which.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
“Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. She watched the distant figure hammering away in the yard, sawdust swirling around him like a strange, sunlit fog. Her grandmother glanced up from her sewing, eyes crinkling. 

“Not ships, exactly,” she said. “But he’s building something to carry him far.”

Alie pressed her nose to the window, curiosity prickling. Everyone in the village seemed to be building something these days—boats, rafts, even those strange contraptions that looked like wings. She wondered if her brother dreamed of the sea, or of the sky.

“Do you think he’ll leave?” Alie whispered.

Her grandmother’s hands paused over the fabric. “Maybe. Or maybe he’ll build something that brings him home again.”

Outside, her brother straightened, shielding his eyes from the sun. For a moment, Alie imagined him sailing over the waves, or soaring above the clouds, chasing new horizons. She hoped, whatever he built, it would carry him safely back to her.

"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked, watching the flicker of lantern light in the shed down the lane. Her uncle nodded, his pipe glowing in the dusk.

"Aye, though not the kind that float."

Alie tilted her head, puzzled. "What kind, then?"

Her uncle coughed a laugh. "He builds ships for the mind, girl. Books. Stories. Maps to places he’s never seen."

Alie crept closer to the window, peering in. Her cousin sat hunched over a desk, ink smeared on his fingers, parchment scattered like sails. She watched him draw lines and scribble words, building worlds where rivers ran backward and stars sang.

"Will his ships ever sail?" Alie whispered.

"If you read them, they will," her uncle said softly.

Alie smiled, the mystery suddenly clearer. Not all ships needed water, after all. Some just needed a good story and someone willing to climb aboard.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked.

responses.text:
"Is he building ships, too?" Alie asked, her breath fogging the window as she watched the flurry of movement in the neighbor's yard. The new boy, Luca, was stacking planks and drawing chalk lines on the ground. His mother liked to say he was an inventor, but Alie’s imagination ran wilder than that.

Grandpa peered over his book, a smile tugging at the corners of his mouth. "Not ships for water, little star," he said. "He’s building ships for the sky."

Alie’s eyes widened. "Spaceships?"

Grandpa nodded sagely. "Or so he claims. He says he’ll fly past the moon by the harvest festival."

Alie watched as Luca fastened a bucket to the end of a plank, then stuck a broom through the handle. It didn’t look like any ship she’d seen, but she felt a flutter of hope in her chest. Maybe, if she asked, he’d let her be a co-pilot. Maybe together, they could sail beyond the stars, leaving behind the sleepy village for galaxies unknown.

Last week, I dreamed I was deep underwater, sunlight slicing through the blue, and a whale gliding alongside me. It looked me in the eye, and I felt something crack open—a calm, low-frequency hum vibrating in my chest. When I woke up, I deleted all my news apps. Now, every morning, I watch whales before I even get out of bed. I like to think, somehow, the whales are watching back.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. My feed has become an endless scroll of gentle giants, their bulk moving with a grace I’ve never managed on land. It’s mesmerizing—the way they breach, the slow-motion roll as sunlight glances off barnacled backs. Sometimes, late at night, I turn the sound up and let the low, echoing calls fill my room. 

People ask why I’m obsessed, and I never know how to explain that watching whales makes me feel small in a good way. It helps me remember the ocean is still out there, vast and mysterious and untouched by my daily worries. Last weekend, I drove out to the coast. I stood on the cliffs, phone in hand, hoping for a glimpse of the real thing. The sea was empty, but I waited anyway, letting the salt air and the endless blue wrap around me. It felt like enough.

responses.text: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text:
I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her waking hours. She had vanished one crisp autumn evening, the gorse and heather painting the hills in gold and violet. For weeks, he searched, his boots growing thin and his hopes thinner. Then, on midsummer’s dawn, she returned: her eyes shimmering like dew, her voice twisted with songs of places he’d never know.

She told of emerald palaces that grew from the roots of ancient yew, of feasts where laughter was sweet and wine never ran dry, and of a queen whose smile promised eternity with a hint of sorrow. But the cost of such splendor was her memory of home, her father’s voice, her own name. The faerie glamour faded when she stepped onto mortal soil, leaving her with nothing but longing and a terror of sleep. In the end, she could not bear it. The man still walks the cliffs at dusk, listening for music only she could hear, and cursing the beauty that stole her heart and left him with only silence.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed at her soul. She returned to the world with eyes glazed and voice hollow, her laughter echoing with the memory of crystal streams and endless twilight feasts. The villagers whispered about the night she vanished, carried away by lights that danced in the mist, and how she reappeared, her feet bare and her hair tangled with silver leaves.

He told me the faeries’ land was a trap, dazzling mortals with its wonders until they forgot the taste of bread and the warmth of a father’s embrace. She tried to explain, but he could not follow her words, which fluttered on the air like moths toward a flame. As the days waned, her longing for that impossible beauty grew unbearable, and so she slipped away, seeking peace beyond mortal cares. The Manx man now keeps watch on the moors, warning children not to follow the music, lest the faerie kingdom claim another soul.

For a time, she tried to live as before, tending to the sheep and mending nets, but nothing in the human world could compare to those enchanted groves and jeweled rivers.

Every night, she dreamed of gold-laced forests and laughter like bells, but also of shadows whispering beneath the roots and bargains struck in silence. The beauty had been a gilded cage, and she was its songbird, set free but unable to sing. The Manx man never blamed her for seeking escape. He spends his days leaving offerings of bread and milk at the ancient stones, hoping the faeries might one day show mercy—or at least leave the rest of them be.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty was a curse. The man described how she returned, silent and shivering, her eyes always fixed on a point just beyond the horizon. She never spoke of what she’d seen, but when she walked, wildflowers bloomed where her feet touched the ground, and the air shimmered with the faintest trace of otherworldly music.

He suspected the faeries had given her every delight, but at a terrible price: she could never find joy in the mundane world again. She wandered the island’s cliffs at sunset, searching for a way back, or perhaps for oblivion. When she was gone, the man was left with only her shadow, a lingering melody, and a fear that beauty, when it comes unasked and unearned, can be as destructive as any nightmare. Now, he warns every child not to follow the will-o’-the-wisps, lest they too be lost to longing.

The man tried to anchor her to the world with stories and salted bread, but she slipped further each day until, one morning, she was gone. Now, he wades into the sea at dawn, letting the cold waves bite his ankles, and listens for her song on the wind, a haunting echo of a beauty too wild and sharp for mortal hearts.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The neon afterglow of the night still clung to her skin, like confetti she couldn’t quite brush away. She shuffled through the quiet apartment, feet catching on stray shoes and memories. The kitchen clock ticked out the seconds since she’d left the laughter behind. Coffee, she thought, though the idea of anything but sleep felt heavy. She poured water and watched it swirl, her mind replaying Bastian’s stories, his wild plans, the way he’d made everyone believe they were on the verge of something miraculous. Now, with the sunrise bleeding gold through the blinds, she wondered if the magic was real or just another shadow that faded with the night. She sipped her coffee and listened to the city waking up, thinking maybe, just maybe, she could find a little bit of that party-light within herself for the day ahead.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The night had been loud—full of laughter, clinking glasses, and stories that grew taller as the hours stretched on. Now, in the gray hush before sunrise, she felt the ache in her bones, the weight of too little sleep and too much memory. She sat on the edge of her bed, staring at the dress she’d worn, sequins catching stray beams of light. Bastian’s voice echoed in her ear: "Stay up a little longer, just for me." She’d stayed, of course. She always did. But now, with the world still half-dreaming outside her window, she wondered what she might give herself if she said no, just once. The thought lingered as she closed her eyes, letting the morning slip by, promising herself that next time, she’d try.

But for now, the city was quiet, and she allowed herself a moment of peace before the day began, promising to tuck this sunrise memory somewhere safe, next to the ache in her bones.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Maybe tomorrow, she thought, she’d find rest. But for now, she simply closed her eyes and listened to the city waking up, letting herself drift between the memory of the party and the promise of a new day.
