Yet I learned to measure privilege not by what I owned, but by the gentle hands that reached for me when I finally said, "Enough." My circle—friends with spare couches and open hearts—helped me see that privilege is sometimes simply the freedom to ask for help and expect it to be given. When I stepped into that empty apartment, sunlight streaming through bare windows, I felt both the ache of ending and the rare, humbling gift of beginning again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. My friends think it’s strange, but I find it soothing. Maybe it’s the contrast—my phone buzzing with deadlines and drama while these massive creatures just do their thing, unconcerned. One night, after a long shift, I scrolled through a new post: a blue whale gliding through turquoise water, its fluke disappearing into the deep. At that moment, my apartment felt tiny, almost suffocating. 

I started walking to the harbor at dawn, coffee in hand, watching the water for any sign of life. The city was quiet, the world paused. Sometimes, if I squinted, I imagined a whale’s back breaking the surface, just for me. I never saw one, but I kept going, my phone filled with their online lives. Eventually, I realized it was less about the whales and more about the reminder: somewhere out there, life continues at its own pace, unconcerned with the noise. That was enough.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It started as a joke—my ex said I was obsessed with big, slow things—but now it’s a comfort. Sometimes I’ll rewatch a video of a humpback rolling in kelp, the water swirling around its giant fin, and the rest of the day feels a little softer. 

Last spring, I booked a whale-watching trip. The boat was crowded and smelled like diesel, but I didn’t care. When a minke surfaced, close enough that I could see the scars on its back, I forgot to take a picture. I just watched, letting the quiet power of the animal fill me up. Afterward, I kept scrolling through my feeds, but it felt different. The real thing was messier and more intense than any video. Still, sometimes at night, I replay the sound of the whale’s breath in my head—a reminder that there’s a world bigger and slower than mine, just beneath the surface.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text:
I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. I don’t even remember when it started—probably during lockdown, when the walls felt too close and I needed something vast. Now, my feed is a blue-green mosaic of barnacled backs and sunlight filtering down to impossible depths. 

Sometimes, I’ll catch myself narrating their slow ballet, imagining myself weightless and unhurried. Once, a video looped of a calf nuzzling its mother, and for a whole afternoon, I felt oddly soothed, like I’d borrowed some of that patient energy. My phone screen becomes a window, and I wonder what the whales would think if they knew we watched them from so far away. Probably nothing—they have krill to chase and currents to ride. Still, when my own life gets too noisy, I close my eyes and drift with them, just for a moment, through a world that moves at the pace of tides.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s oddly addictive—the slow arcs and lazy rolls, the soundless glide through endless blue. On bad days, I lose myself in their world, scrolling through footage of humpbacks breaching or orcas slicing through kelp. 

Once, I tried explaining it at a party, but people just laughed. I guess it’s weird, but there’s something comforting about these gentle giants, far away from traffic and emails and news alerts. I’ve started dreaming about them—sometimes I’m riding on a whale’s back, looking down at the mottled sunlight below. I wake up feeling like I’ve traveled somewhere ancient and secret. Maybe one day I’ll see a whale in real life. Until then, I’ll keep tapping through their slow, silent updates, letting them remind me that there’s a world out there bigger than my problems.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.

responses.text: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. Lately, it’s gotten to where I recognize individual whales by their scars or the way their tails flick. I even named them: Big Lenny, Patch, and The Duchess. It’s like a secret club where the only rule is to marvel at creatures so huge they seem to bend time. One night, after a stressful day, I dreamed I was in the ocean, gliding beside them. The water was cold and endless. Lenny nudged me with his barnacled nose, and I laughed—a sound that echoed weirdly underwater. When I woke up, my phone pinged. New post: Patch, breaching at sunset, water sheeting off her back like liquid gold. For a second, I felt a rush of connection, a weird kinship across screens and continents. Maybe it’s silly, but it helps. Watching whales reminds me the world is full of mysteries I’ll never solve, and that sometimes, it’s enough just to watch, and wonder, and let go.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. In fact, it was practically inevitable. Each evening, as the sun slid behind the hilltops, Mira would climb to the highest point in her little town and peer through her battered telescope. For weeks, she had tracked the arc of a distant comet, its icy tail a whisper of pale blue in the night sky. No one else believed her when she said it would come close—closer than any comet in living memory. But tonight, as she adjusted the focus, Mira’s heart thudded. The comet burned brighter than ever, streaking across the velvet sky. She had calculated this moment, dreamed about it, and now she was the first to see its arrival. In the hush of the hillside, Mira called her friends, her voice trembling with excitement. They would all remember where they were the night the sky touched earth, and Mira would always know: it was more than possible. It was destiny.

It was more than possible. It was already happening. Jasper could feel the subtle shift in the air as he crossed the threshold of the old greenhouse. The scent of earth and forgotten flowers mingled with a strange sweetness he hadn’t noticed before. He had read about magical places, but he never truly believed in them until now. As he wandered among the tangled vines, a soft glow emanated from beneath the cracked tiles. Curious, Jasper knelt and brushed away the dirt, revealing a cluster of bioluminescent mushrooms. The light pulsed gently, almost as if it were breathing. He reached out, hesitating for a moment, then touched the edge of the cluster. Instantly, warmth rushed up his arm and a vision filled his mind: the greenhouse alive again, bursting with colors and life. Jasper grinned. Restoring this place wasn’t just possible—it was waiting for him to begin.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was practically guaranteed, or so everyone told Lena when she announced her plan to build a garden above the city streets. The rooftops were barren and gray, the old tar paper peeling in the sun, but Lena saw patches of green in her mind’s eye. She gathered neighbors, scavenged containers, and hauled bags of soil up countless flights of stairs. Rain barrels appeared, seeds were swapped, and soon, shoots poked through the dirt. Some days, the wind threatened to tear the young plants free, but Lena and her friends shielded them with makeshift windbreaks. By midsummer, the rooftop was a lush oasis, bees buzzing and tomatoes ripening in the heat. Looking out across the city, Lena smiled. It hadn’t just been possible—it had been inevitable, once hope took root.

It was more than possible. It was the kind of thing that seemed destined, the way the old clock in the hall always chimed at midnight, no matter how often it was wound. For years, Julian had walked past that clock, barely noticing the dust gathered on its brass face. But tonight, as the moonlight pooled on the floorboards, he stopped. The clock’s hands pointed to twelve, but the chime was silent. Julian reached out and, almost by instinct, pressed gently on the glass. A soft click echoed, and the wall behind the clock shifted, revealing a narrow staircase spiraling down. Heart pounding, Julian stepped inside, realizing some secrets are more than possible—they’re waiting to be discovered.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was an invitation. When the last train left the station, the platforms emptied, but Vera lingered, her gaze fixed on the darkened tunnel mouth. She’d heard stories—of midnight trains that ran off schedule, carrying passengers to places not found on any map. Tonight, a hush settled, broken only by the distant hum of steel. The hidden train emerged, lanterns glowing with an otherworldly light. The conductor, pale and smiling, tipped his hat. "Boarding for elsewhere," he announced. Vera hesitated, suitcase in hand, then stepped forward. As the doors closed behind her, the city faded, replaced by a landscape stitched from dreams and memory. For the first time, Vera realized the impossible wasn’t just possible—it was already waiting for her, rumbling down hidden tracks, ready to change everything.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every morning, he left a note on her pillow—a scribble of affection, a gentle reminder that he was thinking of her. She read them with a mix of guilt and longing, wishing the words would spark something inside her. They went on long walks by the riverbank, his hand always reaching for hers, his eyes searching for meaning in her silence. She tried to mirror his gestures, to echo his laughter, but it felt like she was performing a role she’d never auditioned for. One evening, as the sun cracked the horizon, she turned to him and whispered, “I want to love you the way you love me.” He smiled softly, brushing a strand of hair from her face. “Just start by being here,” he said. In the quiet that followed, she realized that maybe love didn’t have to look the same on both sides. Maybe being present, trying, and learning was its own kind of love. And so she stayed, hoping her heart would catch up to her hope.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His love was loud—surprising her with flowers, flooding her inbox with sweet messages, making grand gestures that everyone else seemed to envy. Hers was quiet and unsure, a flicker of warmth that sometimes felt more like gratitude than passion. She admired the way he could give so freely, but when she tried to reciprocate, her words caught in her throat and her hands fumbled with small tokens of affection. One rainy afternoon, as they watched drops slide down the window, she finally confessed her struggle. He took her hand, squeezed it gently, and said, "You don’t have to love me the way I love you. Just love me in your way." She realized, then, that love didn’t always have to be symmetrical. Maybe her careful listening, her presence, and her attempts—however clumsy—were enough. And as the rain eased, she felt something inside her shift, not into the love he gave, but into the love she could give.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His love was effortless, natural—like breathing or blinking. He looked at her as though she held every answer he’d ever sought. She, on the other hand, felt as though she was deciphering an ancient language, one with confusing rules and silent letters. She tried—oh, how she tried! She mimicked his gestures, left him notes, forced her smile to match his enthusiasm. But each night, she lay awake, wondering if love should be this hard, this uncertain. One night, as she gazed at him sleeping, she realized love couldn’t be forced, or copied, or borrowed. It had to be found, nurtured, and grown. She decided to tell him the truth in the morning. If love was meant to bloom, it would do so in its own time—and if not, perhaps she owed it to both of them to let him go, so they could each find the love they deserved.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. To him, love was simple—a word, a gesture, a future woven together effortlessly. To her, love was a puzzle with missing pieces. She watched the way he smiled, how he listened, how he remembered every detail about her. She wanted to give him the same certainty but found only questions. One evening, as they sat beneath a canopy of stars, she confessed her fears. He listened quietly, no trace of disappointment in his eyes. "Maybe love doesn’t have to look the same," he said. "Maybe you loving me your way is exactly what I need." The relief was subtle but profound. She leaned on his shoulder, letting herself feel, not forcing what wouldn’t come, but trusting that, perhaps, her way of loving could be enough.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His love was a wildfire—bright, consuming, impossible to ignore. Hers was a cautious ember, hesitant to spark, wary of being extinguished. At night, she traced his sleeping silhouette in the darkness, wondering if her heart could ever catch up to his. She painted him in her journal—sometimes as a lighthouse guiding her through fog, sometimes as a bird she was too afraid to let land on her open palm. She searched for the right words, the right gestures, but everything felt borrowed and unnatural. One day, she filled a box with all the small things she noticed—his favorite tea, a pressed flower from their first walk, a poem she’d scribbled on a napkin. When she handed it to him, her voice trembled. "This is how I love," she whispered, unsure if it was enough. He smiled, holding the box to his chest. For the first time, she saw his love soften, reshaping itself to fit beside hers—two different flames, finally burning together.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was inevitable, or so Mara told herself as she glanced at the battered envelope in her hand. The key, cold and heavy, fit perfectly into the lock. The door creaked open, releasing a faint scent of lavender and old paper. Shadows danced on the walls as Mara stepped inside, heart pounding. She remembered her grandmother’s stories about secret rooms and hidden letters. As she explored, she found a loose floorboard in the parlor. Beneath it lay a dusty journal with her name inscribed on the first page. Mara realized then that some mysteries aren’t found—they’re inherited.

It was more than possible. It was a certainty, at least in Jacob’s mind. The old oak tree behind his house had always seemed special, but tonight, it shimmered with an otherworldly glow. He approached carefully, clutching the pendant his grandmother had given him. As he touched the tree’s rough bark, a gentle hum vibrated through his fingertips. On the other side, he found himself in a world where dreams took shape, and every hope he’d ever dared to harbor awaited him. At last, Jacob realized, sometimes the line between possible and impossible is thinner than a whisper.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was a promise whispered on the wind, a certainty that could not be ignored. As the clock struck twelve, the sound of a distant whistle echoed through the mist. Lila took a deep breath, her heart thundering. The train emerged from the darkness, its lights glowing like twin moons. With a leap of faith, she boarded the first car, unsure of her destination but certain, at last, that she was exactly where she needed to be.

It was more than possible. The odds were stacked in his favor, and still, Marcus hesitated on the rooftop, the city lights sparkling below like scattered jewels. He’d calculated the trajectory a dozen times, checked the wind, ensured his parachute was perfectly packed. But as he stared at the gap between buildings, doubt crept in. Then, from the street below, a familiar voice called out, reminding him why he was here. Marcus steadied his breath, took a running start, and leaped. For a moment, he soared—a brief, exhilarating flight—before the chute snapped open, carrying him safely down. Tonight, possibility had become reality, and Marcus knew he’d never doubt himself again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. It was destined, or so the old legend claimed. Each year, the townsfolk gathered on the windswept cliffs beneath the lighthouse, eyes fixed on the horizon. Young Arun, clutching his grandmother’s silver compass, felt a strange pull—an invitation from the unknown. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Each idea lumbered through her mind like a bear waking from hibernation, groggy and reluctant. The world outside her window was pale and watery, sunlight diffused through thick clouds. She sipped her coffee, hoping for clarity, but the bitterness only seemed to echo the fog within her. The day’s tasks loomed, a mountain she couldn’t remember climbing. She glanced at her notebook, the pages filled with lists and reminders, none of which sparked recognition. Was she forgetting something important? Or was the weight she felt simply the accumulation of too many days spent running on empty? She closed her eyes, letting the silence press in, and tried to find a single, clear thought to hold on to. In the hush, she heard a bird singing, fragile and persistent. Slowly, as if following the song, her mind began to lighten. Maybe, she thought, the mountain could be climbed one careful step at a time.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. The world outside her window seemed to move at a different speed, with cars rushing by and people hurrying along the sidewalk. Inside, she watched dust motes spin lazily in the morning light, each one a small universe suspended in amber air. She tried to focus on her book, but the words swam and blurred, refusing to settle into meaning. Instead, she let her mind drift, remembering the taste of summer peaches and the sound of her grandmother’s laughter. Was it always like this on rainy mornings, a sense of longing mixed with the comfort of stillness? She pressed her palm against the cool glass, feeling the gentle vibration of distant thunder. Something was shifting, she realized, not just in the weather, but inside her as well. If she waited long enough, she thought, perhaps the heaviness would lift, and her thoughts would run clear and bright again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She sat at the kitchen table, unmoving, as the clock ticked away the early morning. Each tick seemed to echo in her skull, reverberating with memories she couldn’t quite reach and worries that clung to her like fog. The smell of stale toast lingered in the air, but she couldn’t remember making breakfast, or even what day it was. She pressed her palms to her temples, trying to coax some sense or clarity from the sluggish procession of her mind. Outside, children’s laughter rose and fell like a distant song, sharp and bright against her dull interior world. She wondered if she’d ever feel light again, if her mind would ever move like water over smooth stones, effortless and clear. For now, she sat and listened to the world, hoping the heaviness might eventually shift, if only a little.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. It was as if her mind had been dipped in syrup, every idea trudging along, weighed down by the invisible. She blinked at the computer screen, words jumbling together, refusing to form coherent sentences. The usual spark she relied on for her work had dimmed to a faint glow. She stood up, pacing the small apartment, the sound of her footsteps muffled by old carpet. Outside, a gray rain began to fall, tapping softly on the window. She watched it gather and trickle down the glass, mesmerized by its aimless journey. Maybe she needed a break, she thought. Maybe she needed to let herself simply be, without demanding answers or productivity. She made tea and wrapped herself in a blanket, letting her mind drift, trusting that the heaviness would pass in its own time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. It was as if she were walking through molasses, each memory a blurred shape pressing against her from all sides. She sat in the attic, knees drawn to her chest, surrounded by boxes of forgotten things—a cracked snow globe, faded photographs, a music box that hadn’t played in years. The dust motes spun lazily in the shafts of sunlight, and she reached for a photograph, her hand trembling. The faces stared back, familiar yet distant. She tried to recall the sound of their voices, the warmth of their arms, but the recollections slipped through her fingers like water. Tears welled in her eyes, unbidden but not unwelcome. She needed this heaviness, she realized, to remember and to heal. As the afternoon waned, a gentle breeze stirred the air, lifting a strand of hair from her cheek. Maybe, in this attic of memories, she could find a way to move forward, one gentle breath at a time.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty could break the heart. He told me this in a low, trembling voice as we sat by the fire in a small pub on the Isle of Man. He said the faeries lured her with music that sounded like spring wind through bluebells, with feasts that shimmered like moonlight on the sea. For a year and a day, she danced and dined and dreamed, but the beauty became a cage, a cruelty disguised in gold and green. When she returned, her eyes were always fixed somewhere just beyond the horizon, and nothing on this earth could satisfy her hunger for the faerie world. Eventually, she faded, her laughter growing hollow, until one morning they found her by the cliffs. The man’s hands shook as he finished his tale, and I saw in his eyes something of that distant longing—a grief so deep it bordered on enchantment. I often wonder if the faeries ever regret what they steal from us, or if they even know the damage they cause.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty gnawed at the soul. He told me she vanished on Midsummer’s Eve, lured by tinkling laughter and the scent of wild thyme. When she returned, she was changed—her voice lilting with songs no one knew, her eyes reflecting colors not seen on this earth. She would not speak of what happened, but at night, she wandered the moors, searching for a doorway back to that place. The man said she wept for its splendor, but trembled at its cruelty. The faeries had shown her wonders, but always at a price: joy so sharp it bled, love so fierce it scorched the heart. After a year and a day, she could bear it no more. The man said the wind still carries her laughter over the heather, mingled with the faerie bells, and sometimes, when the mist is thick, he feels her hand in his, light as a sigh, longing for home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty haunted her even in daylight. He told me, eyes rimmed red, that she returned with silver leaves tangled in her hair and the scent of dew on her skin. She would speak in riddles, recounting banquets of light and music, yet always with a tremor in her voice. She confessed that the faerie world was a prison of perfection, each petal sharper than a blade, each note of music a reminder of her captivity. The loveliness became unbearable—she could never again see the world as it was. In her despair, she left behind a journal filled with sketches of impossible gardens and swirling, sorrowful poems. The man clung to this journal, as if it were a map to her lost soul. Sometimes, on misty evenings, he read her verses aloud, hoping his words might drift across the thinned veil and bring her peace where beauty no longer wounds.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty left her hollow. He said she came back changed, her eyes reflecting a foreign light and her laughter always tinged with sadness. She described palaces woven from spider silk and rivers that sang lullabies, but each story ended with a shudder, as if beauty itself had turned to poison. The faeries, he claimed, were kind and cruel in equal measure, offering wonders while stealing her sense of belonging. After she returned, she wandered the cliffs at dusk, longing for the impossible and unable to settle in the world she had left. In the end, the ache of beauty unreal and unreachable proved too much. The father keeps her last letter, written in a trembling hand, where she begs forgiveness for loving a world that never truly let her go.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

responses.text:
Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. Her boots crunch softly against the gravel as we make our way down the path behind the old greenhouse, our breaths small clouds in the evening air. I try to decipher her mood—was it annoyance, curiosity, or something darker? I clutch the worn slip of paper tighter in my pocket, feeling its edges press into my palm. 

At the gate, she stops. "You sure about this?" she whispers, her voice trembling just enough for me to notice. I nod, not trusting my own voice, and push open the gate. The garden beyond is wild, overgrown, but I know the statue is somewhere inside, just as the letter said. We walk in silence, the tension thickening with every step until we reach the center. Michaela brushes past me, kneels, and starts clearing away the ivy. 

"Here," she says, holding up a small key. For a moment, her eyes meet mine, and I see the flicker of a smile—relief, maybe, or triumph. Whatever it is, I know we’ve crossed a threshold. There’s no turning back now.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The air between us vibrates with words left unsaid, memories we both carry but rarely acknowledge. We move together down the dimly lit corridor, the old floorboards creaking beneath our steps. Shadows flicker along the peeling wallpaper, and I can’t shake the feeling that the house itself is listening.

At the end of the hall, Michaela pauses, her hand hovering over the tarnished doorknob. "Are you ready?" she asks, her voice barely above a whisper. I nod, though I’m not sure if I am. She pushes the door open. The small room beyond is filled with the scent of lavender and dust. Sunlight filters through lace curtains, casting strange patterns across the faded rug.

Michaela steps inside, and I follow. She glances back, her expression softer now. "It’s time," she says. Her words hang in the air as I take a deep breath, steeling myself to face the past we’ve both tried so hard to forget.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows.

We reach the door at the end of the hall. Paint peels from its surface, and the brass handle is cold beneath my hand. Michaela stands close, her breath barely stirring the air between us. I turn to her, searching for a sign—approval, hesitation, anything—but her face remains a mask.

I open the door. Inside, shadows gather around stacks of boxes and forgotten furniture. Michaela slips past me, her movements graceful and deliberate as she kneels by an old trunk. She glances up, finally allowing the hint of a smile to break through. "This is it," she says, voice hushed. Whatever secrets lie ahead, I realize, we will face them together—her unreadable look now an invitation.

Michaela throws an unreadable look in my direction and follows. The night is thick with fog, muting the city’s lights and dampening every sound but our footsteps. I sense the question she wants to ask hanging between us, but she keeps her silence, lips pressed in a determined line.

We wind through the alley, past piles of rain-slicked cardboard and graffiti-tagged walls. I check the address one more time, heart pounding, before pushing open the rusted gate. Michaela hesitates only a second, then slips through after me.

Inside the courtyard, the world feels miles away. Moonlight glimmers on broken glass, and somewhere a cat yowls. Michaela steps closer, her eyes searching mine for answers. I shrug, unsure if I have any. She exhales, the tension in her shoulders finally easing. "Let’s just get this over with," she murmurs, but there’s a trace of a smile as she takes the lead, disappearing into the shadows, and I realize she trusts me more than she lets on.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text:
Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The laughter and music from the night before still echoed in her ears, even as the pale morning light crept through her curtains. She rubbed her eyes and sat up, feeling the ache of too little sleep and too many memories swirling in her mind. The scent of spilled wine and citrus lingered on her skin, mingling with the cool air of her empty room. 

She padded quietly to the window, watching the sleepy world outside. The street was empty, save for a lone cat weaving between parked cars. She wondered if Bastian was awake yet, or if he was still lost in a dream, sprawled across his living room floor. The party had felt like a celebration and a farewell all at once, each conversation tinged with something unspoken. 

She took a deep breath and let it out slowly, promising herself that today she would rest. But as the sun crested the horizon, painting the sky in gold, she knew rest would have to wait. There were still things to do, and the world, as always, would not pause for her fatigue.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The shadows under her eyes felt like badges of some strange victory, proof she’d survived another night of awkward toasts, wild stories, and the cacophony of voices that always grew louder as the hours slipped away. In the gentle silence of morning, she sat on the edge of her bed, feet brushing the cool floorboards, the remnants of laughter and spilled secrets still drifting in her memory.

She padded to the kitchen, making coffee as quietly as she could, afraid to disturb the calm. Outside, the city was just stirring—newspapers thumping onto doorsteps, birds testing their songs. She remembered the way Bastian had smiled at her as the party ended, a brief, tired smile that said more than words could. She wondered if he was awake now, or if he, too, was floating somewhere between exhaustion and anticipation, neither fully asleep nor truly awake.

She wrapped her hands around her mug, letting the warmth seep in. Today, she promised herself, she’d move slowly, savoring the hush after the storm, letting her tiredness be a soft place to land.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:
She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. His affection was sunlight—warm, unwavering, almost too much. Each morning, he would bring her coffee, just the way she liked it, and in his eyes, she saw hope and adoration. Yet, inside her, love was a puzzle with missing pieces. She tried to mimic his gestures, holding his hand a little tighter, smiling more brightly, but it felt rehearsed. 

At night, when the world was quiet, she’d listen to his breathing and wonder if he could sense her uncertainty. She wanted to match his devotion, to give him the security he gave her. So one evening, she told him the truth: that she cared for him deeply, but love was something she was still learning. He smiled, squeezed her hand, and said, “That’s enough for now. We can learn together.”

In that moment, she realized that love wasn’t always a grand gesture—it could be a promise to try. And with that, the missing pieces began to fall into place.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every day, she watched him move through the world with a gentle certainty, always reaching for her, always ready to listen. His words were soft, his laughter easy, but inside her, she felt a tangled knot she couldn’t undo.

She tried to follow his lead, mimicking the small kindnesses he offered, the way his eyes lit up when he saw her. But each gesture felt borrowed, a line in a script she hadn’t learned by heart. She wondered if he could sense the hesitation behind her touch.

One night, under the pale kitchen light, she confessed her confusion. He reached for her hand, steady as ever, and said, “You don’t have to love me the way I love you. Just love me in your way.”

She smiled, tentative but honest, realizing that maybe her way was enough. And as the days passed, she began to find her own rhythm, learning that love could grow quietly, in the spaces between words and the silence of understanding.

He seemed to possess a secret map to the lands of intimacy and devotion, walking their winding roads with ease, while she wandered lost, uncertain of the direction to take. She envied the ease with which he showed affection—the quick squeeze of her shoulder, the reassuring words, the patient understanding when she retreated into herself.

She tried to follow his lead, mimicking his kindnesses, hoping that love would follow the actions. But her heart felt like a locked room with no key, and she feared he would one day notice the emptiness echoing inside. Yet, he never complained, never asked her to change. Instead, he waited, gentle and unassuming, as if love could be grown with time and patience.

Perhaps, she thought, his way of loving was the lesson—love as acceptance, love as patience. Maybe she could learn, even if it took her a lifetime, and that would be its own kind of love.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

responses.text: It was more than possible. In fact, it was inevitable, at least according to the old woman at the bus stop. She sat hunched on the bench every morning, feeding crumbs to the pigeons, telling anyone who would listen that the city would soon be covered in wildflowers. Most people hurried by, dismissing her words as the ramblings of someone lost in memory. But Jamie listened. Each morning, he noticed a few more green shoots poking through the cracks in the sidewalk, a few more petals scattered across the grey stone. By the end of the month, the city had changed. Rooftops blazed with color, vines curled around traffic lights, and even the air seemed softer. People slowed down, breathing in the sweet scents. Jamie found the old woman waiting at the park, smiling. "You believed," she said, handing him a tiny seedling. He smiled back, knowing the city would never be the same.

It was more than possible. It was inevitable, or so Maya told herself as she stared at the blank canvas in her studio. The idea had been growing in her mind for weeks, a stubborn seed refusing to be ignored. Every brushstroke felt like a risk, each color a decision that could ruin the vision or bring it closer to life. Outside, the rain tapped steadily against the window, a metronome for her anxious thoughts. She mixed the paints and began, letting instinct guide her hand. Hours slipped by, unnoticed. When she finally stepped back, exhaustion and exhilaration warred in her chest. The painting wasn’t perfect, but it was alive—vivid, pulsing with emotion. For the first time, Maya understood: sometimes possibility is just the invitation. It’s the courage to begin that brings a dream into reality.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: It was more than possible.

Static crackled, then—clear as a bell—a song from his childhood filled the room. Ravi grinned wide, heart thumping. Sometimes, he realized, the only thing standing between possible and real is a little hope and a steady hand.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s the closest I get to hearing his voice, the scratch of his pen, the way his brow furrows as he searches for a word. Every page is a puzzle, every margin a map back to him. He leaves notes in the manuscript—sometimes cryptic, sometimes tender, always him. I edit gently, preserving his odd turns of phrase, his stubborn love of semicolons. When he returns, he always asks what I’ve changed. I tell him: not much, just dusted the corners, swept the cobwebs from his paragraphs. He smiles, and I know he trusts me with his words. Sometimes, late at night, I imagine the book finished, printed, and placed carefully on our shared shelf. Until then, I keep working, stitching us together with sentences, binding us in paragraphs, holding his story close when the world feels too wide.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s a strange arrangement, I know—him, the writer, and me, the silent collaborator. I fix the grammar he skips in his rush, rearrange the chapters he tosses around like puzzle pieces. I read his characters like old friends, searching for the places where he’s left bits of himself behind. Sometimes I find a phrase that makes me laugh, and I wonder if he wrote it just for me. At other times, I stumble on a passage so raw and honest that I have to close the laptop and breathe. He never asks about those moments, but when we’re together again, he always brings me coffee and sits close, as if words alone could never bridge the distance between us. Yet, each time I open his manuscript, it feels like a conversation, an invisible tether that keeps us connected until we share the same space again.

Still, I persist, because when he reads my words and smiles, it feels like the gap between us is just another paragraph waiting to be rewritten.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too.

responses.text:
Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The taste of late-night laughter still clung to her, mingling with the distant echoes of music that floated through her mind like feathers. Her shoes—now abandoned by the door—had collected stories and wine stains, and her hair still smelled faintly of bonfire smoke. 

She moved slowly through her apartment, every muscle reminding her of the night’s excesses. The city outside was just beginning to stir, sunlight peeling over rooftops, painting her kitchen in gold. As she filled the kettle, she caught a glimpse of herself in the window—smudged mascara, but a pleased, crooked smile. Last night had been a rare celebration, a gathering of friends who felt like family, and she let the memory of it warm her. 

Today would be gentle. She promised herself soft things: a favorite book, a long bath, maybe even a nap under the old blue quilt. Whatever the world needed from her could wait. For now, she let herself be tired, grateful for the joy that caused it.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The world outside her window was still, stained with the pale blue of early morning, but inside, her mind replayed every fragment of the night before. She remembered the laughter, the clinking of glasses, the way music pulsed through the crowded living room, and how Bastian had spun her around until her feet barely touched the ground.

Now, the only sound was the slow drip of coffee in the kitchen. She wrapped herself in a blanket, settling on the windowsill, letting the cool air wake her slowly. The exhaustion was deep, but not unwelcome; it was the kind that followed a night spent living fully. She sipped her coffee, eyes drifting to the horizon, and wondered if Bastian was awake yet, or if he, too, was caught between the remnants of celebration and the demands of a new day. For now, she let herself rest, content in the quiet aftermath, grateful for the tiredness that meant she’d danced and laughed and lived.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. My career thrived, and I had a home in the heart of the city, marble countertops and floor-to-ceiling windows. To the world, I looked blessed. But behind closed doors, my life was a careful choreography around my husband’s moods. He was charming, successful, and always made sure our arguments left no visible scars. I learned to smile for photos and keep secrets at dinner parties. 

Still, I was luckier than most: I had a friend, Lila, who saw through the façade. She’d slip me books about courage and leave little notes in my purse—reminders that I deserved better. One rainy Tuesday, her text arrived: “You don’t have to stay.” That evening, something inside me shifted. I packed a small bag and walked out, not caring about the marble, the view, or the carefully constructed life. 

Privilege, I realized, is having the freedom to choose your own ending. Mine was just beginning.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a supportive family, financial stability, and a career that allowed me to travel. Sometimes I wondered if I deserved to complain when so many suffered in silence without resources. My husband’s words cut, his anger unpredictable, but I could buy myself a weekend away, escape to a hotel, or confide in a trusted friend. 

One night, after dinner ended in slammed doors and silence, I packed a suitcase and drove to the coast. The wind off the sea felt like a baptism. I sat by the window, sipping coffee, replaying the years I’d spent shrinking myself to fit his expectations. My phone buzzed with apologies, but I let it ring. 

In the morning, I called my sister. "I think it’s time," I said. We made plans. With privilege came the power to leave—and I took it, grateful to finally step into a life of my own making.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text:
Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I had a job I loved, friends who cared, and a spacious apartment filled with light. My life looked perfect on paper—designer dresses, lavish parties, and trips to Paris. Yet at home, words turned sharp and cold, and I tiptoed around his moods as if navigating a minefield. 

My privilege was my safety net—the knowledge that if I ever needed to leave, I had somewhere to go. I had family who would take me in, enough money saved for a fresh start, and the independence that so many women in my position lacked. It took months, but one morning while he slept, I slipped out with a single suitcase. 

I left behind the marble countertops and the silence. My privilege wasn’t just material—it was the freedom to choose myself, to begin again, and to finally breathe without fear.

Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. I never worried about putting food on the table or paying the bills. My education and career opened doors that many never even see. My suffering was real, but it wasn’t compounded by poverty or lack of access. I could afford therapy and had a therapist who didn’t judge me.

Yet privilege didn’t shield me from loneliness. I moved through our beautiful home like a ghost, my husband’s criticism echoing in every room. But my privilege gave me options. I could book a flight to visit my brother across the country or spend a weekend at a quiet retreat. Eventually, I realized that privilege also meant power—the power to say enough, to build a different life.

When I left, I did so with support and resources. I learned that privilege doesn’t erase pain, but it can offer a way out.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

There, in the quiet, I met a group of women gathered for a writing circle. They welcomed me, no questions asked. We wrote our stories, raw and unfiltered, and for the first time I realized I wasn’t alone. 

My privilege was the ability to tell my story and to have it heard. That was the spark I needed. Piece by piece, I wrote my way out, until my life was no longer defined by someone else’s rage, but by my own hope and truth.

I drift with a pod, feeling the current tug at my sides. There’s no phone, no scrolling, just the slow, endless blue.

When I wake, my phone is on my chest, still playing a video of a humpback breaching in slow motion. I watch it again before getting up. For a moment, the traffic outside my window sounds like waves, and I think I could live like this—half on land, half adrift, always watching, always almost there.

My friends think it’s weird, but I can’t help it—they’re hypnotic. The way a massive tail flicks a spray of saltwater, the glint of sunlight off a barnacled back, the slow, deliberate movements that make everything else seem frantic.

Last month, I started posting my own sketches of whales, inspired by the endless scrolling. My followers are still mostly bots and my cousin, but that’s fine. Yesterday, a marine biologist DM’d me after I posted a drawing of a sperm whale calf. She sent a voice note—her voice warm, a little shy—saying she loved my work. This morning, I posted another drawing—a blue whale, mid-dive. I hope she sees it. Maybe she’ll send another message. Maybe, one day, I’ll see a real whale for myself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

My new life waited, uncertain but mine, and for the first time in years, I felt the weight of gratitude settle gently on my shoulders.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged.

responses.text: Despite my toxic marriage, I was privileged. One crisp autumn morning, I looked at the golden trees outside my window and decided privilege could be something else: a ladder. I called my sister, packed a suitcase, and stepped into the world beyond our front door—finally ready to use what I had to find freedom.

Some women I met at the shelter where I volunteered had never known options; their stories far heavier than mine. That knowledge haunted me, even as I returned each night to a home filled with cold silences and polished silver. My privilege didn’t lessen the pain, but it offered escape routes: friends with spare rooms, a passport, savings tucked away in a secret account. It took years, but one evening, as the city lights flickered outside my bedroom window, I gathered my courage. I called a friend, packed a small bag, and walked out—determined to build a life measured not by privilege, but by peace.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how.

responses.text:
She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. The feeling pressed on her chest like a heavy stone. Every morning, she watched him make coffee, the way he smiled at her, the way his eyes softened when she spoke. She tried to mirror it, to reflect something bright and deep back to him, but it always felt like she was imitating a language she didn’t quite understand.

He never seemed to notice. Or perhaps he did, and loved her all the same. When he reached for her hand, she let him, fingers entwined, and sometimes she almost believed she could learn—like a muscle, like a song. But at night, when he whispered his dreams into her hair, she felt the divide between them: something invisible, tender, and aching. She wished that love could simply be a decision, but it never was.

Still, she stayed. Not out of obligation, but hope. Hope that one day she would wake up, and the stone would be gone, replaced by the wild, easy certainty she saw in his face. Until then, she kept trying, learning the language, one hesitant word at a time.

She wished that she could love him in the same way that he loved her, except she didn’t know how. Every gesture he made—folding her laundry, leaving notes on the fridge, humming her favorite song—felt like a secret code she couldn’t quite decipher. She admired his warmth, felt grateful for his patience, yet inside her, something fluttered against the cage of her ribs, uncertain and restless.

She tried. She baked his favorite bread, she listened to his stories, she laughed at his jokes, even when they weren’t funny. But her affection always felt like a borrowed coat—too big, too unfamiliar. Sometimes she wondered if love was supposed to be effortless, or if it was something you grew into, with time and kindness.

One evening, as autumn mist crept along the windows, he took her hand and said, “You don’t have to love me the way I love you. Just be here.” And in that moment, her heart softened, just a little. She realized maybe love wasn’t about symmetry, but about showing up, imperfect and hopeful, again and again.

The next day, the account DM’d me: “Want to see whales in person?” I laughed it off—spam, probably. But the offer kept nagging at me. What if it was real? What if I could escape the hum of my apartment and the endless notifications, and just drift for a while, like the whales?

Two weeks later, I stood on the deck of a research boat off the coast of Vancouver Island, salt wind in my hair. When a gray whale surfaced beside us, I felt the ground drop away. I belonged, for a moment, to their world.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s oddly comforting, seeing something so big and ancient just… exist. Sometimes I imagine they’re tuning in, watching us scroll through our tiny screens, wondering what we’re doing with our time.

One afternoon, as I swiped through my feed, my phone vibrated with a message from @whalewatchersunited. “Would you like to join our livestream tonight?” it read. The message seemed automated, but I accepted anyway, curiosity outweighing caution.

That night, I watched as a marine biologist narrated a live video of a pod of orcas slipping through the glassy water. Suddenly, the camera dipped beneath the waves, the world filling with blue light and the distant, echoing songs of whales. My problems felt small and far away. It was only then I realized: maybe I wasn’t just watching whales; maybe I was learning how to drift, too.

responses.text:

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. One night, I dreamt I was a whale, gliding through the deep, sunlight slanting down in golden shafts. When I woke, I couldn’t shake the feeling of weightlessness. I spent the day at the aquarium, pressing my hand to the glass, imagining the salt in my mouth and the echoing calls. Maybe I’ll never see a whale in person, but for now, the videos are enough—a gentle reminder that some worlds are bigger than likes and comments, and sometimes it’s okay to just drift.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text:
Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Each idea dragged itself across her mind as though wading through thick mud. She blinked, uncertain if the room was truly as dim as it appeared, or if her senses were simply dulled by exhaustion. The ticking of the clock on the wall sounded distant, a faint reminder that time was moving, even if she wasn’t. 

She sat at her desk, staring at the unfinished letter, pen poised but unmoving. The words she wanted to write hovered just out of reach, drifting away whenever she tried to grasp them. Outside, rain tapped gently on the windowpane, a soothing rhythm that threatened to lull her into sleep. But she couldn’t sleep—not yet. There was something she needed to say, something important, but the weight in her mind pressed down harder with every minute. 

A sudden memory floated up: laughter at a summer picnic, sunlight glinting off her mother’s hair. The heaviness eased, just for a moment. Taking a deep breath, she let the memory anchor her, and slowly, the words began to trickle onto the page.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She sat on the edge of her bed, fingers tangled in the blanket, trying to summon the energy to move. The world outside her window was painted in soft gray light, rain streaking down the glass in lazy rivulets. Each drop seemed to echo the sluggish pace of her mind.

She remembered the letter on her desk—the one she’d been meaning to answer for weeks. The words she wanted to write muddled together, refusing to take shape. With a sigh, she stood and crossed the room, forcing herself to pick up the pen. The weight of unspoken feelings pressed on her chest like a thick fog, blurring the boundaries between yesterday and today.

As she stared at the blank page, a single tear slipped down her cheek. It wasn’t sadness, exactly, but a sense of being unmoored, drifting. Still, she pressed the pen to paper. Slowly, haltingly, the first words came. They weren’t perfect, but they were hers. And as she wrote, the heaviness in her mind began to lift, just a little.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text:
Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. She shuffled through the kitchen, the morning sunlight barely making a dent in the haze clouding her mind. Even the coffee seemed to lack its usual magic; the warmth in her hands was comforting, but the caffeine did little to sharpen her senses. She stared at the refrigerator, trying to remember what she’d opened it for. Milk? Eggs? A memory flickered, then faded before she could catch it.

Outside, the world moved on—children’s laughter filtered in from the street, a distant siren wailed and faded. She pressed her forehead against the cool metal of the fridge, willing herself to focus. Somewhere in the mess of her thoughts was a to-do list, urgent and unfinished. But for now, she closed her eyes and breathed, letting the heaviness settle as she reminded herself: sometimes, all you can do is wait for clarity to return.

Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. The words on the page blurred as she tried to focus, her brain resisting every effort to make sense of them. She lifted her head, staring at the ceiling, searching for a spark—anything to ignite her usual curiosity. Instead, she found only the dull ache of fatigue, pressing in from all sides.

She wondered if she’d always felt this way or if it was something new, something brought on by the endless days and silent nights. The clock ticked, loud and insistent, but she couldn’t bring herself to care about the passing time. With a sigh, she closed the book and let it drop to her lap. Maybe tomorrow, she thought. Maybe tomorrow her mind would be hers again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her thoughts felt slow and heavy.

responses.text:
Her thoughts felt slow and heavy. Even the air seemed dense around her, each breath thick with memory and regret. She wandered the overgrown garden at the edge of the property, weeds curling around her ankles like the tendrils of the past. The old willow tree beckoned—a silent sentinel that had witnessed her childhood laughter, her teenage tears, and now, her uncertain adulthood. She traced her fingers along its rough bark, grounding herself in its quiet strength. 

Somewhere in the branches, a bird sang a hesitant note, as if testing the weight of the day. She listened, willing her mind to follow the melody, to rise above the sluggish current tugging her down. With a deep exhale, she sat beneath the willow’s canopy, closed her eyes, and let the world slow with her. In the hush, she found a strange comfort: even heavy thoughts could yield to the gentle promise of renewal.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text:
If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s become a ritual, almost—a way of keeping us close even when miles stretch between our apartments. Each day, after my classes, I crack open the battered notebook he entrusted to me. The pages are dense with his handwriting: sometimes hurried, sometimes looping and neat, always alive with ideas. I edit, annotate, and sometimes add questions in the margins for him to answer later.

Tonight, rain taps against my window as I read a passage about a lost city. I can almost hear his voice in the descriptions, earnest and hopeful. I imagine him, somewhere across town, pacing or making tea, trusting me with these words. When we do meet again, we’ll talk through my notes, argue about phrasing, and laugh about the things that don’t quite make sense. Until then, the book is our bridge—a quiet collaboration that keeps us tethered, even when circumstance pulls us apart.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It’s been that way ever since the accident, when he lost the use of his hands but not his words. He dictates chapters to me in the quiet hours of the evening, his voice low and steady, his eyes closed as he conjures entire worlds. When I’m alone, I type up his words, smoothing out the rough edges, adding punctuation where he forgets it in his excitement.

Sometimes, I wonder if it’s truly his story anymore, or if it’s becoming ours—my choices blending with his imagination, my edits shaping his memories. Still, I know he trusts me. It’s a strange intimacy, working on something so personal for someone I love, especially when I can’t always be by his side. But when I finish a chapter and read it aloud to him, watching his face light up, I know I’m exactly where I’m meant to be.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.

responses.text:
If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. It started as a favor, really, but now it’s become something of an obsession. His characters have taken root in my mind, and I find myself arguing with them late into the night, rearranging scenes, tweaking dialogue, and sometimes even scribbling notes for new chapters he never outlined. I wonder if he’d mind, or if he’d be amused by the liberties I’m taking with his plot.

I’m not sure when the line blurred between editor and co-author. Some days, I think I’m writing my own story beneath his, layering my hopes and fears beneath the surface of his prose. When he calls to ask about my progress, I hesitate, unsure if I’m betraying him or bringing his vision closer to life. But every time we reunite, he grins at my changes, and I know he trusts me—even from afar.

If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book. The manuscript smells faintly of coffee and rain, and I always keep it on the little desk by the window. Sometimes I catch myself whispering passages aloud, testing the rhythm of his sentences and imagining how he’d react to my edits. He’s meticulous, but he’s also prone to wild tangents, and I spend hours untangling his thoughts, trying to preserve the spark without losing the thread.

Some nights, when the city is quiet, I picture him writing somewhere else—maybe a crowded café or his cluttered kitchen table. Working on his book is like chasing his shadow, a way to stay tethered when life insists on keeping us apart. When I close the manuscript, I feel a little closer to him, as if the distance between us is just another story waiting to be written.

responses.text: If we’re not in the same room, then I’m usually working on his book.
