Each hour stretched thinner, hope and fear tangled in my chest. I gripped her old scarf, inhaling the faint trace of her perfume, and closed my eyes. Somewhere out there, she was waiting. And somewhere, I had to believe, others searched with the same fierce devotion. Until she returned, I clung to that fragile trust, the only thing keeping me from unraveling.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. It’s a mantra I repeat with every passing hour. The police say they’re doing everything, but their calm professionalism feels cold. My friends check in, bringing casseroles and soft words, but no one can fill the space she left. I spend my nights by the window, scanning the empty street for her familiar silhouette, and my days tracing her last steps. Sometimes I see a flicker of worry in the eyes of the search volunteers. Sometimes I wonder if they will tire, if their hope will fade before mine does. But I can’t do this alone. So I pin her photo up on every lamppost, answer endless questions from strangers, and trust—because I must—that somewhere, someone else is searching just as desperately, unwilling to let her become just another missing person. It’s the only way to keep hope alive.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. It’s not easy, not when I feel the ache of her absence every moment. The house has grown quieter, each ticking clock a reminder of how long she’s been gone. I watch the officers as they comb through the neighborhood, searching for clues, talking to neighbors. Their voices are hushed but determined, and I cling to their assurance that they won’t give up. Friends bring food and hugs, their presence a fragile comfort. I replay her last words to me, searching for meaning, for any hint I missed. The waiting is the hardest part—knowing I can’t control the outcome, can’t join the search myself. All I can do is trust, and hope, and believe that those out there searching feel the same urgency I do, that their hearts break a little with each passing hour. It’s the only way forward.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The words replay in my mind as I sit on the porch, the search party’s flashlights flickering in the distant fields. I want to run to them, to shout her name myself, but Dad says it’s better to let the experts work. The neighbors bring tea and gentle assurances, but their smiles never quite reach their eyes. I wrap myself in Mother’s old cardigan and listen for news—any news. Each night, I light a candle in the window, a small beacon in the darkness. Maybe she’ll see it, maybe someone will. I have to believe that, even when the hours drag long and hope feels thin. Without that trust, I’d sink into the worry and fear, and I can’t let that happen. Not yet.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Outside my window, the city’s neon lights flicker, casting strange shapes on the walls. It’s been three days since she vanished. I’ve scrawled her name on slips of paper and tucked them into the hands of strangers on the subway, posted her photo in every café and alleyway. Yet still, I am just one voice in a sea of noise. The detectives say they’ll leave no stone unturned, but I hear the impatience in their voices. My mother was always the one who believed in the kindness of others. Maybe now is the time for me to do the same: to imagine a network of invisible threads connecting those who search for her, each tug fueled by hope. Somewhere, someone is following a new lead, a neighbor is remembering a detail, a friend is making another call. I close my eyes and picture them all, moving through the city’s labyrinth, determined, relentless. For my mother, for me, for the possibility that trust can be the bridge that brings her home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The detective’s voice on the phone was patient but tired, promising again that they were doing everything they could. I believed him, or at least I tried to. Every passing hour made it harder. I searched the woods myself, flashlight bouncing across fallen logs and tangled roots, calling her name until my throat was raw. Each time my phone vibrated, I hoped for good news, but it was always a neighbor or cousin asking if there was any update. I wanted to shout that it wasn’t enough, that someone needed to do more. But when I saw the search party’s muddy boots and wild, worried eyes, I remembered: I’m not alone. In the chill of the evening, wrapped in my mother’s old sweater, I watched the volunteers comb the hills, their headlamps flickering through the darkness. Maybe, just maybe, hope could outlast fear. I closed my eyes and whispered a silent promise: I won’t give up, not tonight, not ever.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. It’s a fragile conviction, easily battered by the silence of unanswered calls and the slow ticking of the clock. I pace the living room, her favorite mug untouched on the table, the scent of her perfume lingering in the air. Outside, the search team moves through the fields with flashlights, their voices muffled by distance. I imagine each of them picturing someone they love—hoping that empathy will fuel their determination. Sometimes I wonder if worry has made me selfish, if my fear overshadows the efforts of those who’ve joined the hunt. But then the door swings open and a neighbor enters, cheeks flushed from the cold, holding a worn scarf I recognize immediately. She presses it into my hands and I feel a flicker of gratitude. I am not alone in this search. The world may feel empty, but it’s filled with people who care, who will not give up. Hope is a thread I cling to, knotted tightly between all of us who want her home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The thought circles in my mind as I sit on the porch swing, watching the sun slide behind the distant hills. The sheriff’s car is still parked at the end of the gravel drive, its blue lights casting an eerie glow. Neighbors wander through the fields, their flashlights bobbing like fireflies in the dusk. I want to be out there too, but they insisted I rest, that I’d be no good to anyone if I collapsed from exhaustion. I grip the armrest, knuckles white, fighting the urge to sprint into the darkness. Every so often, someone returns to check on me, to offer water or a gentle word, and I see the worry etched on their faces. It’s a comfort, a reminder: I am not alone. Hope flickers behind my ribs, small but steady. If I lose faith in them, I lose the last thing holding me together. So I watch, and wait, and believe that together, we’ll bring her home.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. That faith wavers every time the phone rings and it’s just another friend asking if there’s any news. I want to shout that I need more than sympathy—I need action. But then I see the search parties trudging through the rain, their jackets soaked, their faces set with determination. I remember the neighbor who brought over dinner so I wouldn’t have to cook, the volunteer who stayed up all night combing the woods. Their kindness catches me off guard. I realize now that caring isn’t always loud; sometimes it’s the quiet persistence of those who refuse to go home until she’s found. So I try to settle my racing heart and trust the process. I keep the porch light on and the kettle warm, waiting for the door to open, believing that hope, multiplied by many, is stronger than fear.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But in the feverish hush of midnight, when the police radios go silent and neighbors retreat to their own worries, it’s harder to believe. I wander the empty kitchen, tracing the pattern of her favorite tablecloth, remembering how she’d hum to herself as she baked bread. My mind drifts to the stories she told me as a child—of lost things finding their way home, of hope kindled in the darkest woods. I try to hold onto those tales now, whispering them like prayers. Maybe the world is bigger than my fear, and maybe care is a web spun from a hundred hands—some I’ve never met, all reaching out for her. I lean against the window and watch the distant flicker of flashlights, small stars in the thick night. I breathe in, steadying my heart. Somewhere out there, people I barely know are calling her name, searching. I trust them. And in the silent kitchen, I promise my mother: I will not stop believing she’ll be found.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, Mia stepped into the gentle rain, her suitcase clutched tightly in one hand. The city lights blurred in the downpour, casting gold and blue streaks across the glistening pavement. She paused at the corner, heart pounding, and looked once over her shoulder. The apartment window glowed warmly, but she couldn't bear to see his silhouette. Leaving without a word felt wrong, but words had always failed her when she needed them most. So she pressed forward, letting the rain mask her tears, her footsteps fading into the city's lullaby. Tomorrow would bring new choices, new regrets, and perhaps, someday, the courage to say hello again.

Without a goodbye, Daniel closed the door behind him, the echo of its latch hanging in the empty hallway. He hesitated, his fingers still resting on the cold knob. The apartment, silent and shadowed, seemed to hold its breath. He’d left a note on the kitchen table—nothing elaborate, just a few lines scrawled in haste. He knew he couldn’t face her eyes, the questions, the disappointment. So he stepped into the night, the city’s hum swallowing his footsteps. He didn't look back. In the gentle hush outside, Daniel wondered if not saying goodbye was kinder, or just another way of running away.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the old clock in the hallway ticked louder than ever. Clara stood by the window, watching the first morning light creep across the sleeping town. She knew by the emptiness of the house—no creak of the floorboards, no kettle whistling in the kitchen—that he was gone. A note might have softened the silence, a word, a glance, but instead she was left with only questions and the slow unfolding of each lonely hour. The world outside went about its business: the mailman whistled, a car passed. But inside, time seemed suspended, waiting for a farewell that would never come.

Without a goodbye, the garden gate swung shut behind Lila. She walked down the gravel path, the stones crunching under her worn shoes, and breathed in the sharp scent of dew. The sky was streaked with pale pink, promising a new day, but her heart lingered in the shadows she left behind. She hadn’t planned to leave so quietly, but when morning arrived, she knew she couldn’t bear the weight of parting words. With every step, she hoped one day she’d return—or at least that the memories she left would blossom in her absence, like the wildflowers she’d planted by the fence.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the last train pulled away from the station, leaving only the echo of its whistle curling through the midnight air. Niko stood on the empty platform, clutching a faded photograph, the ink smudged from years of hopeful handling. The city behind him was a patchwork of glowing windows and silent streets, but he felt invisible, untethered. He remembered the stories his grandmother used to tell—about bridges that only appeared for those brave enough to cross without looking back. As the wind rustled his coat, Niko took his first hesitant step forward, no ticket, no plan, only the certainty that some journeys begin where words fail, and endings dissolve quietly into the night.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

responses.text:
“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man’s mirrored sunglasses catch the morning sun, and he smirks, brushing imaginary lint from his suit sleeve. Jonah, leaning against his battered Civic, watches as the man circles the car, inspecting for invisible flaws. 

“Nothing wrong with making an entrance,” the man replies, his voice velvet-smooth.

Jonah shrugs. “Depends what you’re entering.”

The man’s smile widens. “The auction. You here for the Van Loon painting?”

“Just watching,” Jonah says. “But I do like a good show.”

The man laughs, then produces a slim envelope from his pocket. “You might get more than you bargained for.”

Jonah’s eyes narrow. “What’s that?”

“A little wager,” the man says, stepping closer. “Winner of the painting gets the other’s car.”

Jonah grins, brushing dust from his Civic’s hood. “You sure?”

The man’s Ferrari gleams in the sunlight. “Very.”

As they head inside, Jonah can’t help but think: sometimes, it pays to play the underdog.

“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The stranger pauses, flashing a grin that glints as much as his watch. “Sometimes you have to announce your arrival,” he replies, tossing his keys to the valet with a flourish.

Jonah laughs, folding his arms. “You announcing something, or compensating?”

The man’s eyes flick up and down Jonah’s faded jeans and thrifted jacket. “Why not both?” he says, unbothered, striding toward the restaurant entrance.

Jonah follows, curiosity piqued. Inside, everyone turns to stare. The man walks like he owns the place. Jonah, trailing behind, wonders if he ever felt that way. They slide into a booth, menus untouched.

“So, what brings you to town?” Jonah asks.

The man leans in, lowering his voice. “Let’s just say I’m here to find something that was never supposed to be found.”

Jonah’s pulse quickens. “And you think it’s here?”

The man only smiles, eyes glinting. “I’m sure of it. Want to help?”

Jonah hesitates, then nods. Sometimes, subtlety is overrated.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

responses.text:
"Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man pauses, giving Jonah a once-over, then shrugs with a sly smile. “It gets me where I need to go.”

Jonah chuckles, pushing his sunglasses up. “And where’s that? Monaco?”

The man’s lips twitch. “Not today. Just the library.”

Jonah raises an eyebrow. “You planning to read or impress?”

"Maybe both," the man replies, glancing at the library’s stone steps. “Knowledge and style aren’t mutually exclusive.”

As the man heads inside, Jonah follows, curiosity piqued. Inside, the man moves with purpose, heading straight for the rare books section. He pulls a worn leather notebook from his coat, eyes darting across spines. Jonah lingers nearby, watching.

Minutes later, the man finds what he’s searching for—a dusty blue volume, almost hidden. He slips his notebook inside the book, then returns it to the shelf. Catching Jonah’s eye, he tips an imaginary hat.

Jonah grins. Not your average Ferrari driver, after all.

"Subtle car," Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man grins, unfazed. "You noticed? I was hoping to blend in."

Jonah laughs, shaking his head. "Maybe if you parked it behind the dump truck."

The man nods, glancing around the nearly empty parking lot. "Fair point. But then who would know I’m here?"

Jonah shrugs. "Maybe that’s the idea."

They stand in silence, the midday sun glinting off the Ferrari’s hood. The man seems to weigh something, then extends a hand. "I’m Marcus."

"Jonah," he replies, shaking it. "So, what brings you to this side of town?"

Marcus hesitates, then leans in. "Looking for someone who doesn’t want to be found."

Jonah arches an eyebrow. "And you think they’ll come out for a Ferrari?"

Marcus smiles. "Sometimes, the best bait is the loudest one."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari.

responses.text:
“Subtle car,” Jonah says as a tall man with slicked-back hair steps out of the Ferrari. The man barely glances at him, adjusting his cufflinks as if they might catch the light better than the car itself.

“Subtle’s boring,” the man replies, voice smooth as lacquer. He surveys the parking lot, then the sky, as though calculating some invisible equation. Jonah notices a delicate tattoo peeking from the man’s collar—a compass rose, inked in faded blue.

“Expecting to get lost?” Jonah asks, nodding at the tattoo.

The man smiles, cryptic. “On the contrary. I always know exactly where I am.”

He pulls a small wooden box from the passenger seat, tucking it under his arm. As he passes Jonah, he leans in, his cologne sharp and unfamiliar. “Sometimes the best way to disappear is to be the brightest thing in the room.”

Jonah watches him walk into the old hotel, curiosity blooming. He’s seen a thousand flashy cars before, but never a man who wore attention like armor—and secrecy like a second skin.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. Her heart pounded a frantic rhythm in her chest, and she gripped the nearest chair back, knuckles white. The moonlight slanted through the broken window, illuminating the overturned lamp on the floor. She tried to steady her breath. The silence was thick, broken only by the distant drip of water from a leaking pipe. Was he moving? Was he watching her? Each second stretched, taut as a wire. She edged around the table, keeping her eyes on the darkened corner. A low rustle told her he was still there. She considered running for the door, but it seemed impossibly far. Then, a shadow shifted and a voice, barely above a whisper, said, “You don’t have to be afraid.” She almost laughed—almost. But her hand shook as she reached for the pepper spray in her pocket. "Maybe not," she said, voice trembling, "but I am."

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The room was painfully familiar, yet now it felt hostile, every shadow thick with threat. She edged backward, careful not to trip on the scatter of books and broken glass. Her mind raced—had she locked the back door? Was her phone still on the counter, or had it fallen in the chaos? Behind the chairs, she crouched low, willing her breathing to quiet. The thud of his landing echoed still in her ears. Then, from the darkness, a low, ragged breath. He was closer than before. She clutched the heavy candlestick she’d grabbed, feeling the cold metal steady her hand. Silence pressed in. She squeezed her eyes shut, counted to three, then sprang up, swinging the candlestick with all she had. The blow connected with a grunt, and she ran, not daring to look back.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The air felt thick, as if she were moving underwater, every muscle in her body screaming to run. The chairs scraped loudly as she backed away, a crude shield between her and the darkness where he might be lurking. She strained to hear, heart drumming in her ears, but the silence pressed in, heavy and expectant. Suddenly, a faint creak on the floorboards sent her spinning, adrenaline surging. She caught a glimpse of movement—a shadow, or maybe just her own fear reflected in the glass. "Who’s there?" she whispered, voice barely audible. No answer. Her pulse skipped. She tightened her grip on the chair, refusing to let panic swallow her whole. Somewhere, a clock ticked, painfully slow. She braced herself, unsure if she should wait or make a run for it. Either way, she knew she couldn’t stand still forever.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The kitchen, once cozy and warm, now seemed vast and treacherous, shadows pooling in every corner. Her breath caught as she glanced at the back door—it hung open, letting in a cold wind that rattled the windowpanes. She listened, straining for any sound: the scrape of a shoe, the whisper of fabric. Nothing. Still, she edged further away, heart pounding in her throat. The chairs felt flimsy, but they were the only barrier she had. She reached for a heavy mug on the table, fingers trembling. If he moved again, she’d be ready—at least, that’s what she told herself. But she could feel his eyes on her, waiting, calculating. The silence was almost worse than any threat. She swallowed hard, summoning courage she didn’t know she had. "You don’t scare me," she lied into the shadows.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The old parlor was a maze of relics and dust, but she moved with desperate intent, her fingers brushing over the frayed velvet of an armchair. Outside, thunder rolled, shaking the stained-glass window. She heard a low groan, then silence—a predator’s silence. Her mind flashed back to childhood games of hide and seek with her brother, the thrill of being found, the terror of not. Now, the stakes were real. She reached for the fireplace poker, hand slick with sweat. The grandfather clock struck midnight, and the echo seemed to summon a shadow from the hall. He stepped into the light, rainwater dripping from his coat, eyes wild. For a heartbeat, neither moved. Then, with the storm raging behind them, she raised the poker and spoke, her voice steadier than she felt: “If you’ve come for the past, you’ll have to fight for it.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The search party had left at dawn, their flashlights bobbing through the early mist as they fanned out across the hills. I waited on the porch, clutching the worn scarf she’d left behind, its familiar scent of lavender barely clinging to the threads. Every time the phone rang, my heart leapt and crashed. Neighbors stopped by with casseroles and awkward smiles, but no news. I told myself they cared, that beyond the quiet murmurs and worried glances, there was a shared urgency. But the night stretched on, and doubt crept in. Maybe no one could care as fiercely as a daughter. Still, I watched the horizon for headlights, listened to the distant dogs barking, and prayed that someone, somewhere, was turning over every stone. I whispered her name into the darkness, hoping the world would echo it back—and that somewhere, my mother would hear.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. It’s a difficult hope to maintain when each hour ticks by without news. The police officers say they’re doing everything they can, their voices calm and practiced, but I see the fatigue in their eyes. Friends and neighbors have formed search parties, combing through woods and alleys, calling her name into the thick summer air. I hold onto the idea that each person stepping into the darkness tonight carries a piece of my worry with them. Maybe they don’t know my mother’s laugh or the way she hums when she’s nervous, but they understand the ache of missing someone. So I wait by the window, scanning the night for a flicker of hope—a flashlight beam, a kind voice, or the sound of footsteps that might bring her home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The thought circles in my mind as I stand at the edge of the woods, the damp air heavy with the sound of distant voices and the occasional bark of a search dog. Volunteers trudge through the underbrush, flashlights sweeping the darkness, their breath visible in the cool autumn night. I want to join them, to shout her name until my throat is raw, but Dad says I should wait by the car in case she comes back. Every minute stretches into an hour. I try to remember the kindness in the faces of our neighbors, the determination in the rescuers’ eyes. Maybe their love isn’t the same shape as mine, but it’s real enough. For now, that has to be enough. I squeeze my mother’s favorite locket in my hand and whisper a silent promise to both of us: I won’t give up, and neither will they.

I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But anxiety claws at my chest, making it hard to breathe. The living room is filled with people—neighbors, relatives, even strangers—each with their own theories, each determined to help. I watch as they organize maps, divide into groups, and share brief, encouraging words. I want to believe that their hope matches mine, that they’re not just going through the motions. Outside, the late afternoon sun casts long shadows across the yard, and I catch glimpses of searchers combing the fields. I close my eyes and picture my mother, her gentle smile, her soft hands. I have to trust in the goodness of the community, in the power of many hearts focused on one goal. It’s the only way to keep despair at bay until I see her again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

responses.text: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The city pulses on, indifferent to my panic, but somewhere in the maze of sirens and streetlights, I believe people are searching for her. I imagine her face printed on flyers taped to lampposts, strangers stopping to read the bold headline: MISSING. I picture a detective tapping photos against his desk, coffee gone cold, piecing together her last known steps. Even as my doubt gnaws at the edges, I tell myself that compassion can be found in unexpected places—a barista who remembers her usual order reporting a sighting, a taxi driver recalling a conversation. I cling to these imagined allies, building an invisible network of hope. My mother always said kindness is a current: even if you can’t see it, it flows around you. Tonight, I reach for that current, trusting it will carry her home.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. I could see it in the way people glanced at me, a mixture of reverence and fear shadowing their eyes. For years, I had wielded my influence like a blade, carving out a space for myself in a city that never slept. But tonight, as rain hammered the glass penthouse windows, I realized power was a fickle companion. It didn’t comfort me when the phone rang at midnight, bearing news that my closest ally had betrayed me. It didn’t shield me from the loneliness that crept in through the cracks of my carefully curated life. Power, I realized, was not the absence of vulnerability, but its mask. And as I looked out over the city lights, I wondered if I would ever find the courage to let it go.

Yes, I was powerful. I held the world in my hands, or so I thought. With every word I uttered, people listened. With every decision I made, lives changed. But power, I learned, is not just the ability to command others—it’s the burden of their expectations. When the storm came, sweeping through the city with relentless fury, everyone turned to me for answers, for hope. I tried to be the pillar they needed, but the weight was crushing. In the end, I realized true power wasn’t in control, but in compassion—knowing when to lead, and when to let others find their own strength. That night, as the storm passed, I finally understood what it meant to be truly powerful.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. The world bent at my fingertips, my every wish a command whispered into reality. But with each spell cast and each victory won, I felt the walls closing in. Power, I discovered, was a cage gilded with admiration and fear. People no longer saw me; they saw what I could do, what I might become. One moonless night, as I walked alone through the silent garden, I heard a child’s laughter—a sound untouched by ambition or dread. It called to something deep within me, something I thought I’d lost. I knelt beside the tangled roses, letting the thorns prick my fingers, grounding me in the earth and the present. For the first time, I wondered if giving away a little of my power might bring me closer to the world I so desperately wanted to touch.

Yes, I was powerful. The shadows obeyed my call, and the winds shifted at my whim. For years, I shaped the fate of kingdoms from behind veiled curtains, my name spoken only in whispers. But with each victory, the emptiness inside me grew. One evening, as I looked into the eyes of a child orphaned by my own decree, I saw the price of my ambition. Guilt gnawed at my soul, and I realized the true cost of power was the distance it created—from others, and from myself. From that day, I vowed to use my strength to heal rather than harm, to bridge the chasm I had created, and to find redemption in compassion.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Yes, I was powerful.

responses.text: Yes, I was powerful. Not in the way of kings or conquerors, but in the quiet certainty that the world’s smallest creatures held secrets no one else could see. As the city buzzed far below, I perched atop the tallest sycamore, communicating in clicks and chirps with the sparrows at dawn. My power was subtle—a gentle nudge that sent a raincloud drifting south, a whispered note that coaxed a seed to sprout through cracked concrete. No one noticed when I tilted the wind just enough to guide a lost balloon home, or when I sang a melody that soothed the fevered dreams of a child. Yet, in these small miracles, I found a strength deeper than any throne. I was the unseen architect, weaving wonder into the ordinary.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, Maya left the little house at dawn. The streets were silent, her only companions the soft echo of her footsteps and the chilly mist curling around the lamplight. In her backpack, she carried only what mattered: a battered journal, a photograph of her mother, and a half-eaten bar of chocolate. She didn’t look back. She couldn’t risk seeing the window glow with the light of someone waking, or the shape of her father’s face in the glass. Every step forward was heavy with the weight of things unsaid, but lighter than the burden of staying. As the sun began to rise, painting the city’s rooftops gold, Maya felt the first flicker of hope—fragile, but real. She didn’t know where she was going yet, but she knew she was moving toward something new, and that was enough for now.

Without a goodbye, Julian simply vanished. His friends noticed first when he didn’t show up for coffee, but assumed he’d slept in. Days passed, and unease grew. His apartment sat silent, the bed neatly made, the fridge still stocked. Only his old cat, curled on the windowsill, seemed to wait. No one knew that Julian had taken the train north, leaving behind the city’s noise in search of something unnamed. The decision was sudden but not impulsive; the longing had lived quietly inside him for years. On the second morning away, he wrote a letter, not to send but to remember: ‘Sometimes you have to leave to find where you belong.’ In the quiet town beyond the pines, Julian finally exhaled, feeling both loss and relief in the hollow space where goodbye should have been.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the yellow bicycle stood alone at the edge of the field, its wheels damp with dew. Lucy’s laughter, once ringing through the tall grass, had faded into the hush of morning. Her brother, Sam, circled the house in search of her, still clutching the folded paper crane she had left on his pillow. The note inside simply read: "I needed to find the sky." He didn’t understand, not yet, but as the days stretched on, Sam found himself riding her bicycle, chasing the horizon she had set out to find. Each pedal forward was both a question and a quiet hope that wherever Lucy was, she had found the freedom she craved, and would one day send another crane home.

Without a goodbye, the music faded from the old apartment. Rachel’s piano, once the heart of every evening, stood silent in the corner, its keys gathering dust. Neighbors wondered where she’d gone, the landlord left her mail in a neat pile, and the alley cat waited by her window for scraps that never came. In truth, Rachel had slipped away in the night, her suitcase filled with sheet music and dreams she could no longer fit into the cramped, gray city. As she rode the dawn train to somewhere new, she pressed her fingers to the glass, humming a tune only she remembered, carrying her memories forward without looking back.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the last candle flickered out in the cottage window. Elowen pressed her hand to the cold stone, heart pounding, as the wind swept away all traces of her hurried escape. She left behind not only the warmth of the hearth, but the tapestry of stories her grandmother had woven into every nook of the house. Outside, the moonlit woods beckoned, mysterious and wild, promising answers to questions she’d never dared ask aloud. As she stepped deeper into the forest, the hush enveloped her—a world both familiar and foreign. Elowen felt the ache of absence, yet the thrill of possibility crackled in her veins. Somewhere ahead, destiny waited, silent and patient, unconcerned with the farewells she could not bring herself to utter.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, his tone measured but resolute. The room seemed to shrink around them, the hum of the old refrigerator the only sound for a long moment. Sienna’s eyes narrowed, flickering between Gabe and the empty mug in her hand. 

“You weren’t there, Gabe. You didn’t see what happened.” 

He shook his head. “I know I wasn’t, but I know Mari. She doesn’t make things up.”

A silence settled, heavy and expectant. Sienna set her mug down, her hands trembling ever so slightly. “Maybe. But people change. Sometimes you think you know someone, and then—”

Gabe cut her off, his voice softening. “Maybe. But I trust her.”

Sienna looked away, studying the chipped tiles on the countertop. Trust. That was the thing, wasn’t it? She could feel it slipping, like water through her fingers, and she wondered if Gabe was right to hold on, or if she was just too afraid to let go.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. He folded his arms, watching the shadows flicker on the old wallpaper.

Jenna paced the length of the kitchen, her jaw clenched. “Gabe, you can’t just take her word for it. Not after what happened last time.”

He shrugged. “She’s never lied to me before.”

“That you know of.”

Gabe looked at her, his gaze unwavering. “What are you really afraid of?”

Jenna stopped, running a hand through her hair. “That we’re wrong. That we trust the wrong person again.”

Gabe’s lips twitched in the ghost of a smile. “I’d rather trust and be hurt than doubt everyone. Mari deserves that much.”

Jenna turned away, her voice barely above a whisper. “I hope you’re right. For all our sakes.”

Outside, thunder rumbled. Gabe wondered if the storm would pass before the truth finally came out.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. He glanced out the window, where dusk was pooling in the corners of the yard. The accusation hung between them, heavy and unresolved.

Leah crossed her arms, voice trembling. “You didn’t see the look in her eyes, Gabe. She was nervous, and she kept glancing away.”

Gabe shook his head. “She’s nervous because you keep interrogating her. Sometimes people get scared when they’re put on the spot.”

Leah sighed, frustration etched into her features. “I just want to know the truth. If Mari’s telling the whole story, then why does it feel like something’s missing?”

“Maybe you’re looking for cracks where there aren’t any,” Gabe replied softly. He caught his reflection in the window, uncertain himself. But he knew Mari, or at least he thought he did. Trust is a fragile thing, and tonight, it felt like it might shatter at any moment.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. His voice was calm, but his fingers tapped restlessly against the table. Across from him, Rowan’s brow furrowed.

“Gabe, you can’t just take everything at face value,” Rowan said, frustration simmering beneath his words. “She’s hiding something. I can feel it.”

Gabe met Rowan’s gaze, unwavering. “Mari’s always been honest with us. Why would she start lying now?”

Rowan hesitated, then shook his head. “People change. Circumstances change. Maybe she felt like she had no choice.”

A silence stretched between them. Gabe thought about the way Mari had avoided his eyes earlier, the way her answers had come a little too quickly. Doubt crept in, but he pushed it aside. Loyalty, he decided, mattered more than suspicion—at least for now.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, but his words hung in the air, brittle and uncertain. The flicker of candlelight cast strange shadows on the peeling wallpaper as Tessa leaned in, her voice barely more than a whisper.

“Gabe, she told me she saw the silver key. That she found it in your desk.”

He stiffened. The silver key was supposed to be a secret, a relic from the summer when things had gone so wrong. Gabe swallowed, clearing his throat. “Maybe she just guessed.”

Tessa shook her head. “She described it—the shape, the engraving. She even knew about the scar on your hand.”

Gabe’s hand drifted to his palm unconsciously. Mari had promised she wouldn’t tell. But promises, he realized, were as fragile as trust. He looked at Tessa, heart pounding. “What are you going to do?”

Tessa’s eyes glinted with something between hope and fear. “That depends. On whether you’re still keeping secrets, or finally ready to tell the truth.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The two boys hunched on the dock, toes skimming the water, watched as the sun slipped behind the pines. Sam’s voice was still tinged with disbelief. “You’re serious? You found it in the lake?”

David nodded, eyes wide. “Just under the old dock. It was wedged between some rocks.”

Sam glanced over his shoulder at the battered wooden building that served as the camp office. “Should we tell someone?”

David shook his head, pulling a small, waterlogged tin box from his backpack. “Not yet. I want to see what’s inside first.”

They pried it open, and the fading light caught on a tarnished silver locket, a note folded tight, and a photograph of a girl smiling shyly. The name written on the back made Sam’s heart skip: Eliza Hawthorne, 1922.

Thunder rumbled in the distance, and the lake’s surface shivered. “We have to find out who she was,” David whispered, eyes shining. The summer air felt suddenly electric, brimming with secrets, as if the lake itself had something more to say.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Marianne set her goggles down, her breath still ragged from the swim. The water behind her calmed, tiny ripples lapping at her ankles. She glanced at her brother, Lucas, who was staring at something caught in the reeds.

“I saw it, I swear,” Lucas insisted, pointing. “Not a fish. It was...metal. Shiny.”

Marianne waded closer, curious. The day was muggy, dragonflies hovering just above the surface. Then she saw it: a glint of silver, half-buried in the silt. Together, they tugged it free—a small, ornate key, cold in Marianne’s palm even in the sun.

“Looks old,” she murmured, turning it over. There were initials carved into the handle: J.P.

Lucas grinned. “A treasure hunt?”

Marianne hesitated, glancing at the quiet woods and the distant cabins. “Or a mystery.”

The air seemed to thicken with possibility. As they trudged back to shore, the key heavy with promise, the lake behind them shimmered, as if holding its breath, waiting for them to discover what secrets it had unlocked.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Rosa’s voice was steady, but her eyes darted to the far end of the water, where lily pads floated in a lazy cluster. Sam, who’d just arrived from the city, squinted in disbelief. “Are you sure? People don’t usually find things like that out here.”

Rosa shrugged, clutching the sodden letter between her fingers. The ink had bled, but the words were still legible: ‘Meet me at midnight. Bring the lantern.’

They sat in silence, listening to the frogs and distant hum of summer. Sam leaned in, whispering, “Do you think it’s a joke?”

Rosa shook her head, her curiosity outweighing her fear. “I want to see who shows up.”

As the sky darkened and the swimming lake grew still, they waited, the letter between them, a silent promise of something strange just beneath the surface.

In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Callie’s knees pressed into the muddy bank as she fished the old glass bottle from the shallows. Her brother, Eli, peered over her shoulder, his nose wrinkling at the algae clinging to the sides.

“Gross. Why are you even touching that?”

Callie grinned and popped the cork with her thumb. Inside, a faded scrap of parchment curled tightly.

She unrolled it carefully. The handwriting was spidery but readable: ‘Find the heart of the lake, and secrets will be yours.’

Eli rolled his eyes, but Callie’s pulse raced. They’d heard stories about the lake’s forgotten past, about treasures and tragedies. This was the first real clue.

“Let’s go,” Callie whispered, her eyes bright with adventure, “before anyone else finds out.”

Eli hesitated, but curiosity won. Together, they slipped into the cool water, chasing secrets that had waited decades to be found.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Jasper’s voice trembled as the dusk settled over the camp, the lanterns flickering along the shore. I looked down at my muddy hands, remembering how the old compass had glinted beneath the reeds, its needle twitching madly despite the stillness. We’d both heard the stories: the lake sometimes returned what it took, but only if you asked nicely—and only if you promised not to keep it for yourself.

Now, as the frogs chorused and the sky deepened to indigo, Jasper nudged the compass across the dock between us. “We should put it back,” he whispered, voice barely carrying over the night breeze. I hesitated, feeling the weight of a hundred summers in that battered brass. But when I glanced at the water, it seemed to pulse with anticipation, as if the lake itself was listening, waiting.

We stood, side by side, and together tossed the compass into the dark. The ripples shimmered silver, and for just a moment, I thought I saw a pale hand reach up from the depths to catch it. Then the water stilled, and the night closed in, thick with secrets and possibility.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The question echoed through the silent house as Mara tiptoed down the unlit hallway. She clutched her flashlight, heart pounding against her ribs. The air was thick with dust and memories, each room holding whispers of laughter and pattering feet. But the house had been empty for years—at least, that's what the neighbors said.

She reached the old nursery, pushing open the peeling door. Moonlight slanted across the faded wallpaper, revealing a row of wooden blocks scattered on the floor. Mara knelt, tracing the letters with trembling fingers. She thought she heard a giggle, light as wind, but when she spun around the room was empty.

"Are there children?" she whispered again, her voice barely audible. A chill swept through the room, and the rocking chair in the corner creaked gently, as if someone unseen had just left it.

Outside, the wind picked up, rattling the shutters. Mara rose, heart still racing, and left the nursery behind, unsure whether the answer she sought had been yes, or no.

Are there children? The words hung in the air as Mrs. Calloway peered into the misty playground. The swings moved gently, as if pushed by invisible hands, and the sandbox showed tiny footprints that hadn’t been there yesterday. She stepped closer, her cane sinking into the damp grass, and listened for laughter or shouts, but only the distant caw of a crow replied.

She remembered a time when the park was teeming with life—when children ran, tumbled, and shrieked with delight. Now, the neighborhood had changed, and the little ones had all grown or moved away. Still, every morning, Mrs. Calloway came with a pocket full of peppermints, just in case.

That morning, as she sat on her favorite bench, she heard it—a faint giggle, soft as a breeze. She turned, and for a moment, the playground shimmered, bathed in golden sunlight, and shapes flickered: shadows of children playing, caught between memory and morning fog. Mrs. Calloway smiled, content to wait, peppermints in hand, for the laughter to return.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The words slipped from Dr. Benson’s lips as she surveyed the ruins of the once-bustling settlement. Her team fanned out among the crumbling walls and toppled furniture, scanning for any signs of life. She crouched beside a faded mural painted on the stone: stick figures holding hands, suns and flowers sketched in bright, hopeful colors.

The silence pressed in on her, broken only by the crunch of gravel under boots. Then, near the edge of the village, a soft whimper floated on the wind. Dr. Benson signaled, and the team hurried over. Behind a collapsed wall, two wide-eyed children huddled together, clutching each other tightly. Relief and sorrow mingled in Dr. Benson’s heart as she knelt beside them.

“Yes,” she said softly, answering her own question. “There are children. And now, we must help them find their way home.”

Are there children? The question echoed in the clearing as dusk settled over the forest. The travelers paused, uncertain. For days, they’d followed the narrow path winding deeper into the trees, guided only by rumors of laughter and small footprints found in the mud.

A twig snapped. From the shadows, a pair of bright eyes blinked. Then another, and another, until a half-dozen children emerged, silent and wary, their hair tangled with leaves and moss. The eldest stepped forward, chin lifted in defiance. “Who are you?” she asked, her voice steadier than her trembling hands.

The travelers knelt to meet her gaze. “We’re here to help,” one said gently. The children looked at one another, uncertainty flickering in their eyes. In the hush of the twilight, trust hesitated at the edge, waiting for the next move.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
Are there children? The inquiry arrived in a coded transmission, blinking urgently across the pilot’s console as the ship drifted into orbit around the abandoned colony. Commander Reyes hesitated, remembering the legends: that the planet’s last laughter had faded decades ago, leaving only ghosts and wild, tangled gardens. But as she scanned the surface, her sensors detected rhythmic patterns—chalk drawings, marbles in neat circles, a rope knotted for skipping, all untouched by adult hands.

She dispatched a drone, which floated down to a crumbling schoolyard. The playground was eerily silent, but the swing set moved, creaking softly, and a paper airplane soared through the air, propelled by nothing visible. Reyes watched as shadows darted at the edge of her vision, quick and fleeting, accompanied by faint echoes of giggles. The transmission blinked again: Are there children? Reyes typed her reply, uncertain. Maybe not in the way we remember, she wrote, but something of their joy lingers here—enough to make the whole world feel a little less empty.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
"Are there children?" whispered Mara, peering through the crack in the faded curtain. Outside, the village square was empty except for the stray dog that always circled the old well. The silence was heavier than usual; even the birds seemed to have left.

Her younger brother, Eli, clung to her sleeve. "Mama said we shouldn’t talk about them."

Mara nodded, remembering the way Mama’s voice trembled when she mentioned the children, the ones who vanished last winter. Some said they’d gone to the city. Others whispered of the woods beyond the river, where the trees grew too close together and the air smelled of iron.

"But I saw someone last night," Eli said. "A girl, in a blue dress. She waved at me from the apple tree."

Mara’s heart thudded. She drew Eli closer. "We’ll look for her tomorrow," she promised, though the idea filled her with dread. She couldn’t shake the feeling that something was waiting for them in the shadows—something that remembered the children, and wanted them back.

"Are there children?" the woman asked, voice trembling as she peered into the dimly lit room. Her question hung in the air, unanswered, as dust motes danced in the golden shaft of sunlight that crept through the cracked window. The house had been abandoned for years, but the rumors persisted—sometimes, in the dead of night, laughter echoed from within.

She stepped inside, each floorboard groaning underfoot. Her own childhood memories tugged at her: hide-and-seek, whispered secrets, the scent of chalk and old wood. In the far corner, a faded ball lay nestled against a toppled chair.

Suddenly, a giggle rang out, soft but unmistakable. The woman froze, heart pounding. "Is anyone there?" she called, her voice barely above a whisper.

A shadow flickered past the doorway, small and quick. The woman followed, drawn by the sound of more laughter—familiar, haunting. At the end of the hallway, she paused, breathless. The door ahead creaked open just a sliver, and she saw them: spectral, translucent children playing in the sunlight, forever caught between then and now.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
"Are there children?" the inspector asked, scanning the faces of the small crowd gathered at the edge of the forest. No one answered at first. The villagers exchanged nervous glances, their eyes darting between the inspector and the tree line, where the shadows seemed to swirl and shift.

Mrs. Helms, the baker, finally spoke. "We haven't seen them since last night. They were playing near the old stone bridge, but—"

Her words faded as a chill wind swept through. The inspector's grip tightened on his notebook. He remembered the stories he'd heard as a child, tales of the Green Man who roamed the woods and lured away the young.

He took a step toward the trees. "I'll go look. Please, stay here."

As he disappeared beneath the tangled branches, the villagers watched in silence, hoping against hope that the children would be found, and that the old stories were just that: stories.

"Are there children?" The question echoed in the empty hallway. Janice stood in the doorway, clutching her clipboard, uncertain. The house was supposed to be vacant, but she’d heard the unmistakable patter of small feet just moments before.

She stepped inside, heart beating faster, eyes adjusting to the dim light. Toys lay scattered on the carpet—wooden blocks, a frayed teddy bear, a tiny red car. She called out again, softer this time: "Hello?"

A giggle drifted from upstairs, followed by the whisper of footsteps. Janice hesitated, then climbed the creaking staircase, each step amplifying her apprehension. At the top, a door stood slightly ajar. She pushed it open, revealing an empty room, sunlit and still. The laughter had vanished, leaving only the distant hum of traffic outside.

Janice shook her head, uneasy. Maybe the house wasn’t as empty as everyone thought.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are there children?

responses.text:
"Are there children?" The question tumbled from the walkie-talkie and echoed through the abandoned amusement park, bouncing off rusted rides and collapsing ticket booths. Juno pressed the talk button, her breath visible in the cold night air. "Not that I've seen. Just echoes."

She moved cautiously past the carousel, its chipped horses frozen mid-gallop. Somewhere in the darkness, something clattered. Juno tightened her grip on the lantern and stepped closer to the funhouse, where rumors said the missing kids had last been seen. Her own childhood felt like a distant memory, but she remembered the thrill of sneaking into forbidden places.

Inside, mirrors reflected her pale face a hundred times. Then, a fleeting giggle—high and bright. She spun around. A flash of movement: a paper airplane, gliding slowly from the balcony above. Written across its wings: "We are here."

Juno smiled, heart racing. Maybe, just maybe, the children hadn't vanished—they had found a world of their own, somewhere between reflections and dreams. She followed the laughter, ready to believe in magic again.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, Mara slipped out of the small, sunlit apartment that had been her world for the last two years. The city was waking up, its streets humming with the promise of a new day, but Mara walked in silence, carrying only a battered backpack and a heart heavy with unspoken words. She knew if she stayed, she’d never leave. The weight of memories pressed against her, but she pressed on, blending into the crowd. She remembered his laughter echoing in the kitchen, the warmth of his hand finding hers in the dark, and the secrets they never dared say aloud. Now, the only thing left was the echo of her footsteps as she turned the corner, vanishing into the morning light. By the time he woke, the only trace she left was a coffee mug on the table, still warm, and a sense of absence that would linger far longer than any note ever could.

Without a goodbye, the old hound left the porch at dawn. Sarah awoke to the echo of an empty dog bed, the faint scent of rain on the wind. She called his name, voice trembling, but only silence answered. The neighbors hadn’t seen him, nor had the mailman, and the woods behind the house seemed deeper, more secretive than before. Days turned into weeks, and though she left treats by the gate, they remained untouched. One evening, as the sun dipped low, Sarah found a tuft of gray fur snagged on the blackberry bramble. She sat beside it, letting the cool grass press against her legs, and smiled through her tears. Somewhere out there, she hoped, her loyal friend had found whatever he was searching for—freedom, peace, or simply the wild call of the world beyond fences. Sometimes, she realized, the hardest journeys begin without goodbye.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the train pulled away from the station, leaving Rowan standing alone on the empty platform. The last words they’d shared were trivial, spoken with the careless comfort of routine. Now, that comfort felt like a thin blanket in a winter storm. Rowan watched the tracks stretch into the distance, shrouded by morning mist, wondering if the silence between them would ever be bridged. Each day, the city grew louder, but inside, Rowan carried a quiet ache where laughter used to live. Sometimes, at dusk, they’d imagine the other person stepping off a train, returning with a story and an apology. But as weeks blurred into months, Rowan learned to cherish the quiet: the soft clatter of cups, the rustle of a book’s pages, and the steady beat of a heart healing, little by little, after being left without a goodbye.

Without a goodbye, the world felt oddly suspended, as if time itself hesitated in confusion. Joel stared at the empty chair across the breakfast table, the untouched mug of tea growing cold. It was as if Liv had evaporated, leaving behind only echoes and the faint scent of her shampoo. He replayed the previous evening in his mind, searching for clues, a sign, anything to explain her absence. Each night, he left the porch light on, hoping she’d walk up the path, smiling sheepishly, ready to explain. Days turned into weeks, and the silence grew heavy, settling into the corners of the house. Eventually, Joel learned to move through the stillness, filling it with new music, new friends, and the gentle acceptance that sometimes, people leave without a goodbye—and life, somehow, goes on.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Without a goodbye.

responses.text: Without a goodbye, the circus left town overnight, leaving behind only faint tire tracks in the dew-soaked grass and the lingering scent of caramel popcorn. Young Leo, who had watched every show from the shadow of the big top, wandered through the empty field at sunrise. He found a single red juggling ball nestled in a patch of clover, its bright color defiant against the gray light. In that moment, he understood that magic didn’t always announce its departure—it simply vanished, leaving behind fragments for those willing to look. Years later, Leo would become a magician himself, traveling from town to town, always arriving quietly, always leaving without a goodbye, a wisp of wonder trailing in his wake.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. She pressed her back against the cold stone wall, trying to calm her breath as footsteps echoed down the hallway. The candle in her hand flickered, casting strange shadows on the ancient tapestries. She could hear voices now, muffled but urgent, growing closer with every second. Clutching the letter tighter, she remembered why she was here—the secret hidden beneath the old chapel could change everything. The footsteps stopped. Silence. A door creaked open. Someone whispered her name. She forced herself to move, sliding around the corner and into darkness, her heart pounding with hope and fear.

Her heart started beating faster. The world outside the window blurred as the train gained speed, but all she could see was the small envelope in her lap. She traced the seal with trembling fingers, remembering the last time she saw him. The letter held promises—or perhaps confessions—that would change everything. The train rattled, the city lights faded, and she hesitated, caught between the safety of the past and the uncertainty of what lay ahead. With a deep breath, she tore the envelope open, letting the future rush in as quickly as the train itself.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. She could feel every thump echoing through her chest as she stared at the phone screen, the number flashing back at her. It was an unfamiliar number, but something inside told her to answer. With trembling hands, she pressed the green button. "Hello?" she managed, voice barely above a whisper. The silence on the other end stretched, then finally, a voice she hadn’t heard in years spoke her name. Memories flooded in—some sweet, some sharp. She closed her eyes, bracing herself for whatever this call would bring, knowing her life was about to change.

Her heart started beating faster. She glanced down at the clock, realizing she only had five minutes left. The kitchen was a mess—flour dusted every surface, and the oven timer was about to sound. She wiped her hands on her apron, nerves tingling as she peeked at the cake rising behind the glass. Today was her chance to prove herself, to finally impress the judges of the baking contest. As the timer rang, she took a deep breath, pulled the golden cake from the oven, and hoped her dream would finally come true.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Her heart started beating faster.

responses.text: Her heart started beating faster. The forest around her seemed to lean in, the trees whispering secrets in the wind. Moonlight dappled the mossy ground as she stepped carefully over tangled roots, clutching the ancient map in her hand. Every shadow threatened to become the creature from her grandmother’s stories, the one who guarded the hidden well. She had come searching for answers, but now she wondered if she was ready to find them. A twig snapped behind her. She spun, eyes wide, as a fox with silver fur emerged from the underbrush, its gaze knowing and gentle. With a nod, it beckoned her onward, deeper into the unknown.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

We stood at the edge of the water, my toes curling into the cold mud. The morning sun glimmered off gentle ripples; dragonflies dipped and hovered. I glanced at my cousin, who grinned in a way that made me nervous.

“So, what exactly are we looking for?” I asked, pretending I wasn’t scared.

He pointed to a spot near the reeds. “Treasure. Grandpa said he lost his watch here when he was a kid. Gold, with an inscription.”

A heron startled, flapping into the air. I shivered, half from excitement, half from the chill. We waded in, water lapping at our knees. Each step squelched, sending minnows darting. 

“Are you sure it’s still here?”

He shrugged. “Only one way to find out.”

We dove. The world went quiet and green, sunlight slanting through the water. My fingers searched through silt and pebbles. Suddenly, something cold and round brushed my hand. I surfaced, heart pounding, and held it up—just a smooth stone. But my cousin’s eyes widened.

“Try again,” he urged, as if he already knew the story’s end.

“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The distinction mattered, somehow. The Hudson was wild, unpredictable; the swimming lake was supposed to be safe. But as dusk crept over the water, shadows stretched long and thin, and the air took on a chill that made my skin prickle.

Jake tossed a pebble in. “You coming?” he asked, already rolling up his jeans. I hesitated, watching the surface for movement. Last summer, someone said they’d seen something strange—a ripple, a shimmer, a glimpse of silver scales. No one believed them. But I remembered the way their eyes darted, the tremor in their voice.

I stepped forward, feeling the squelch of mud between my toes. “You first.”

Jake grinned and splashed in, disappearing up to his waist. I waded after him, heart pounding. The water closed around my legs, cool and thick. Somewhere beneath us, secrets lingered—old fishing hooks, lost toys, maybe even the thing from last summer.

“Race you to the buoy,” Jake challenged, and dove under. I took a breath and followed, determined to see for myself what the lake was hiding.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

Maya’s voice echoed across the grassy bank, where the scent of damp earth mingled with the faint sweetness of late summer wildflowers. The lake shimmered, a pale green mirror framed by pines. We had all gathered here after the storm, clutching flashlights and old towels, hearts drumming with the thrill of a dare.

“Are you serious?” I whispered, glancing at the others. Ben nodded, teeth chattering. “They say it glows under the water now.”

I knelt by the edge, the mud cold against my knees. It was true—beneath the surface, something flickered, pale and ghostly. “Should we go in?”

Maya was the first to slip in, the water swallowing her gasp. One by one, we followed, our arms and legs moving through the eerie light. The current tugged at our ankles. Something brushed past me—soft, deliberate. I surfaced, coughing, but the others were silent, staring down into the lake’s glowing heart. I realized then that the storm had changed more than the skyline. The swimming lake had claimed a secret, and tonight, it seemed ready to share.

“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The confusion in his voice was almost comical, but I didn’t laugh. I kept my eyes fixed on the water, where the moonlight danced across tiny ripples. It looked peaceful now, but I remembered the chaos of the afternoon—the flash of lightning, the sudden downpour, the frantic shouts as everyone scrambled for cover.

“You saw it, right?” I asked, my voice low.

He hesitated, then nodded. “Yeah. It… it wasn’t normal.”

We waited, listening to the frogs, the distant hum of a car on the highway. I shivered, thinking of what I’d glimpsed under the surface: a shape gliding, too big to be a fish, too fast for a log. I hadn’t told anyone else. They’d just laugh.

But he believed me. That was enough for tonight. We sat together on the dock, feet dangling, watching for another sign that the swimming lake held something more than water and memories.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake.

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.”

The question hung in the misty air, absurd yet oddly plausible after the summer we’d had. I glanced at the rusty lifeguard chair, paint peeling, a silent witness to our secrets. Last night, I’d seen the lantern’s glow drifting along the lake’s edge. Everyone said it was just reflections from the old boathouse, but I knew better. My brother hadn’t come home, and the footprints by the water were too small to be his.

Now, as dawn unraveled over the glassy surface, I waded in, ignoring the chill. My fingers brushed tangled weeds, searching for answers or maybe a sign. “If you’re here,” I whispered, “send me something. Anything.”

A ripple broke the silence. A battered sneaker bobbed into view, laces frayed. I reached for it, heart pounding, and pulled it from the water. Tucked inside, a folded scrap of paper, soggy but legible: ‘Try the willow tree at midnight.’

I glanced back at the shore. The mystery deepened, but one thing was certain—the swimming lake was keeping its secrets close, and I wasn’t leaving until I uncovered them.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. The room fell silent, the only sound the hum of the overhead lights. Elena’s eyes narrowed. “You’re just going to take her word for it?”

Gabe shifted his weight, glancing between Elena and the closed door behind which Mari waited. “She’s never lied to me before,” he said, voice softer now.

Elena crossed her arms. “People change. You know what’s at stake.”

He nodded. The stakes, the missing money, the trust that had held their small group together. Gabe tried to remember every conversation with Mari over the past week, searching for cracks.

The door creaked open and Mari stepped out, her face pale but determined. “If you think I took it, say it to my face,” she said, voice trembling. Gabe looked at her, then at Elena. The truth hovered in the air, heavy and uncertain.

“I don’t think you did,” Gabe said. “But I need to hear you say it.”

Mari met his gaze. “I didn’t.”

For now, it was enough.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. His words hung in the air, brittle as glass. At the far end of the table, Mari sat rigid, her hands folded tightly in her lap.

Tomas frowned. “You don’t even know her. None of us do.”

Gabe shrugged, forcing his voice to remain steady. “I know what she told me. I know she was at the library last night, and I know she had nothing to do with what happened to your car.”

Mari’s eyes flickered with gratitude, but she said nothing. Silence pressed around them, thick with suspicion.

Finally, Tomas slammed his fist on the table. “If you’re wrong, Gabe, it’s your neck.”

Gabe nodded. “Then I’ll take that risk.”

Outside, the wind howled around the old house. Mari finally looked up, her voice barely above a whisper. “Thank you.”

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. The accusation lingered in the air, prickling at the edges of the dim-lit kitchen. Mari stood by the sink, hands trembling as she rinsed her cup. She didn’t turn.

Kara scoffed, folding her arms tightly. “So that’s it? You just believe whatever she says?”

Gabe hesitated. “No, but I trust her more than I trust rumors.”

Mari finally faced them, eyes watery but fierce. “If you don’t believe me, just say it. But don’t pretend you’re protecting me.”

Kara’s jaw clenched. “I want to protect all of us. If you’re hiding something—”

Gabe stepped between them. “Enough. We’ll find out the truth. But until then, we don’t turn on each other.”

Outside, the wind rattled the window. Inside, suspicion grew roots, silent and unseen.

Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. His voice was calm, but there was a flicker of doubt behind his eyes. Across the table, Lena pursed her lips, her fingers tapping out an anxious rhythm.

“Gabe, you know how important this is. If she’s lying—”

“She’s not,” he interrupted, a little too quickly. Mari, sitting quietly between them, looked straight ahead, her expression unreadable.

Lena sighed. “I just want to be sure. We can’t afford another mistake.”

Mari finally spoke, voice steady. “You have every right to question me. But I promise, I’m telling the truth.”

Gabe glanced at Lena, then back at Mari. He wanted to believe her. He needed to. Outside, the rain began to fall, a steady drumming that seemed to echo Lena’s unease. For a moment, none of them spoke. The truth hung in the air, just out of reach.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

responses.text:
Are you calling Mari a liar?”

“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said. His words seemed to echo off the cracked plaster walls of the old train station, where the four of them huddled beneath the flickering light. Rain hammered the windows, and Jess pressed closer to the warmth of the radiator, eyes narrowed.

“Come on, Gabe,” she snapped, “she’s the only one who knew about the signal. The package went missing the same night she was on watch.”

Mari’s chin lifted, defiant in the yellow glow. “If you’re so sure, then just say it. But don’t pretend it’s about trust.”

Gabe looked from Mari to Jess, feeling the accusation swirl in the musty air. He wanted to believe Mari—he needed to—but doubt gnawed at his gut. The package was gone, and with it, their chance at safe passage.

He took a steadying breath. “We don’t have time for this. The train leaves in twenty minutes. Either we stand together, or we’re done for.”

For a moment, no one moved. Then, silently, Mari slipped her hand into her pocket, closing her fingers around the key they all needed, and stepped into the shadows.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text:
She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The room was thick with dust, and every movement kicked up motes that sparkled in shafts of moonlight. She forced her breath to slow as she crouched behind the nearest chair, her fingers gripping the wood so tightly her knuckles ached. The silence spooled out, tense and taut, broken only by the faint, shuffling sound on the far side of the table. 

She peered through the gap between the chairs, heart hammering against her ribs. There was a shadow—too large to be her own—creeping along the wall. He was here. Her mind raced back through every warning, every whispered word of caution she’d ignored. She tried to remember the exit, the window latch, the way out. The shadow paused, and she heard the unmistakable rasp of his breath. One step, then another. She weighed her options, every muscle in her body coiled to spring. This night would end with one of them gone.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The echo of impact still reverberated in her bones, and she clung to the clattering metal as if it were armor. The kitchen’s pale overhead light flickered, casting nervous shadows on the linoleum. Her mind darted from memory to memory—his angry voice, the way he moved in the dark, the promise she’d made to herself: never again. 

A hand scraped the floor just beyond the overturned table, groping blindly. She bit her lip to keep from making a sound. Her heart pounded so loud she feared it would give her away. He grunted and a chair skidded, the screech loud as a siren. She inched backward, her bare feet sliding silently over the cold tile. With the window behind her and the door blocked, she realized she’d have to outsmart him. She closed her eyes, summoned every ounce of courage, and waited for the moment to strike.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text:
She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The old parlor’s silence pressed in, punctuated by the faint scrape of leather on wood. She scanned the shadows, pulse thrumming in her ears. Something—a lamp, a bookend—anything could be a weapon, but her hands only found the chill of polished oak. 

He was close. She saw the glint of his shoe beneath the table, the briefest shuffle. Her mind raced with half-remembered self-defense moves from years ago. Would she fight, or flee? Her body trembled with adrenaline, and yet, a strange calm settled over her as she calculated the distance to the door. If she moved now, she might escape. If she waited, she might learn why he was here. The next few seconds would decide everything. She drew a shaky breath, flexed her fingers, and prepared to choose.

She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land. The living room seemed to shrink, the corners growing darker, the silence oppressive. She gripped the back of a chair, knuckles white, trying to steady her nerves. Her mind replayed the sound—the unmistakable thud of boots—and she wondered how he had found her so quickly. 

A sudden movement—a flash of shadow—made her breath hitch. She forced herself to stay low, knees bent, ready to dash or duck. The chairs were her only shield, flimsy but between them and him. She listened for breathing, for footsteps, for any sign of intent. Instead, there was only the ticking of the clock and the erratic pounding of her heart. If she could make it to the hallway, she might have a chance. But before she could move, his voice, low and menacing, broke the silence: "You’re not going anywhere."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.

responses.text:
She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land.
